summary: Unknown originally number of denaarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 coins were recovered. Among issuers: Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Antoninus Pius, Commodus and other emeperors.
514 imperial bronze coins: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection J. Marcello, Soprintendenza Archeologica di Padova, Italy

summary: (90) 27 denarii: 7 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel.
103 denarii, among which one imitation: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 181).
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: The hoard of 79 denarii (one Republican denarius; imperial coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius) and one Lycian drachm was found in 1882 during plowing of a court at Middels-Osterloog. The coins lay in a container.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.

The 22 coins (sestertii, Trajan - Marcus Aurelius) are the remnants derived from a hoard of at least five pounds from a meadow (Eckenweiher) where Roman villas have been found. The find is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD.
14 denarii found at a distance of a few hundred meters from each other on both banks of the Sonia River, the tributary of the Sona: Titus - Commodus (AD 185).
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

summary: Seven bronze coins: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153) found secreted in a wall of a vaulted storage room during excavation of a granary.
14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: Five bronze coins found one next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.
33 bronze coins found together in one insula of the former Roman city of Baetulo.

Initially, circa 2,050 coins. Only 1,938 enter in the museum collection: 270 republican denarii, 1662 imperial denarii, 5 drachms, 1 as: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166). Found with a bronze jar.
Unknown originally number of coins. 42 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 78.0-122.8 g.

A Roman burial was discovered in the spring of 1929 in widening the south side of the Ashford-Maidstone-London road. This almost certainly represents an untouched cremated deposit. Together with other objects, it contained 18 gold coins or disks.
Unknown originally number of coins. Circa 200 sestertii were seen From Flavians to Septimius Severus (AD 197). Only 29 were available for study.
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, two coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.
A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
Two medallions (Hadrian, Commodus) were found with a vessel. Together were seven bronze tintinnabula, one patera, and two iron objects.
22 denarii found on a cultivated field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174).
disposition: Gabinet Numizmatyczno-Sfragistyczny, Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, Wrocław, Poland

summary: 311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.
109 coins: 105 bronze coins, 4 silver denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163). Also part of the deposit were the head of a hair pin and a ring. Considered as a votive offering.
Hoard of unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic jug. 96 denarii: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193).
disposition: Museum of History, Kyiv, Russia (50 coins; inv.nos. AR/9256-9304); Local History Museum, Chernovitsy, Ukraine (46 coins)

summary: Hoard containing, among others, an aureus of Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva) and an imitation of Tiberius aureus.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,600 aureii, from Julius Caesar to Commodus. Most of the hoard was immediately dispersed and sold.
Hoard of 100 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 185 coins, deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
48 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) (AD 138-161).
disposition: History and Art Museum, Bacău, Romania

summary: The hoard was found during the excavation of a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD.

A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.
The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
Around 400 denarii found with a clay pot. 338 coins are known: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (294 coins), Museum Sandomierz (8 coins), Museum Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski (12 coins), Poland

summary: Galba to Severus. The number of coins in the hoard is estimated and falls somewhere between 1200 and 1500 denarii and 1 drachm of Amisus for Hadrian. Found with a ceramic vessel and few silver ingots.
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum (64 denarii; 1 drachm of Amisus)

summary: 7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.

Around 200 denarii. The person who ppresented 46 denarii mentioned that in total may have found around 200 pieces. Only 28 coins could be described. One denarius of Antoninus Pius was found in 2010: Vitellius - Clodius Albinus (AD 194-197).

The details of the hoard are not well known. Found in 1871 it passed possession multiple times and was eventually split. Originally 387 silver coins were found, and one gold piece, along with several urns. Only 12 pieces are described: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla Augusta).
160 denarii, 80 recovered: 41 republican, 39 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 102-103).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
Hoard of 11 sestertii found adjacent to the large Cadeby hoard.
A hoard of ancient coins, including a tetradrachm of Thassos and a denarius of Faustina I found with a ceramic vessel.
2 denarii: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164); silver weight: 5.33 g.
A group of 27 coins, together with a further silver coin fragment. Addenda of 3.
Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
20 sestertii, found on a small plate with ashes: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-187).

Over 112 denarii found on the top soil scattered. Only 8 coins could be described: Vespasian, Trajan (Marciana), Hadrian (Sabina), Hadrian (Aelius), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Commodus, Commodus (Crispina), Spetimius Severus (AD 194). Circa 25 m from Jerzmanowice 2006 hoard. Most likely one owner.
(c. 220) 151 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: c. 367.1-588.9 g.
Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including two coins of Juba II, one of Nero, one of Galba, nineteen of Vespasian, seven of Titus, twenty-three of Domitian, three of Nerva, forty-eight of Trajan and ten of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified two of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes ten extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: one Republican denarius, one denarius of Vespasian, two denarii of Domitian, five denarii of Trajan and one Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the nine latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
The hoard comprised 218 Syrian tetradrachms from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian.

A very large find of Roman denarii, made in 1858 in the vicinity of Filsum. Around 1960, three further denarii (Domitian Caesar, Commodus) were found on a field, and can probably be connected with the same find.
9 denarii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
The hoard comprised 16 denarii dated between AD 98/99 and AD 128/129.
76 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179).
Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing a block of Roman bronze coins stuck together with corrosion products. Rever identified approximately 180 sestertii and 5 'middle bronzes'. The hoard was found by a labourer digging a hole to plant a tree.
Hoard of 314 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Circa 300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while metal detecting. At the moment, 17 pieces are available for description: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-160).
Denarius hoard consisting of 97 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
410 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 161-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2519

summary: 51 denarii: 16 republican, 35 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 119-122). Together was found a Dacian silver bracelet.

Ten Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.

Five denarii found at different dates, between 2005 and 007, on the same field using metal detectors: Vespasian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Augustus) (AD 171-172).
disposition: Private collection (4 coins); National Museum of archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (1 coin)

summary: During the excavation of the Roman town, 2 small hoards of both silver and bronze were found from below the front of site VI. Hoard A comprised 23 coins, ending with Hadrian.

18 denarii of which two imitations (one hybrid) found as a lump: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). The imitation denarii were struck with the same dies as other two denarii found in Ukraine (Dymowski 2017)
The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.

In 1931, 14 bronze coins (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found on the surface in front of the southern gate of the Roman fort, which were oxidised together in a clump. Some specimens show exposure to fire.

A hoard of 298 aurei dating from Nero to Lucius Verus was discovered in Vienna in 1799 during the construction of the Wiener Neustadt Canal. Of the 298 aurei, 24 were stolen and 274 initially were recovered. There is information for 279 coins: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The average weight of the coins was 6.3g.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (191 coins)

summary: 771 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180); Septimius Severus coin is an intruder. There were two ceramic vessels buried at 2 m one from the other at the same depth of 0.25 m.
disposition: National Museum of History Bucharest; Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra Neamț (Romania)

summary: Some coins, unknown denomination, of Nerva, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius

6 denarii and 1 AE coin, ranging from Domitian to Commodus, found in cellar 207 between 1897 and 1908. These 7 coins of this find were not identified according to inventory number or type and could thus not be separated out from the list of single finds.
A hoard of 257 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176).
disposition: Museum, Dortmund (243 coins); the Ruhr Valley Museum in Schwerte and Fröndenberg (14 coins)

summary: (200) 41 sestertii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (41 coins)

summary: Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
The hoard comprised 2 aurei from Antoninus and Faustina II and 5 denarii from Trajan, Antoninus, Faustina I, Faustina II and Lucilla. It's probably a part of hoard.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.

During the construction of the protestant Alumneum (Gesandtstraße) in 1900, remains of a hypocaust system were found. Within the debris a group of 8 coins - 7 aurei and 1 denarius - were recovered, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius. They might have been stored in a wooden box or leather bag. The hoard's deposition is conjectured to have been linked to the Marcomannic Wars.

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Antonine dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.
A hoard of 74 denarii (Republic- Hadrian), found in 1854 approx. 1 km north of the place, 100 m from the street next to Dahnsdorf behind a hill in a ravine.
Eight denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. One additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: 320 D: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180): Discovered in an onion field after it had been ploughed. The finder carefully collected the coins together, but discarded fragments of the pottery container. Found whilst harvesting onions in a field in the north-western part of the village, next to the road leading to Gruia.

Originally 5 denarii, 2 preserved: Hadrian, Hadrian (Sabina), Antoninus Pius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla); silver weight: 4.61 g. (2 coins). Not certain that they were found together!
865 coins: 29 aurei, 833 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 137-138)
A hoard of 300 Roman denarii ranging from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 74). Only 19 coins have been recorded. Based on the portrait style, the coins seem to be imitations of known genuine types.
disposition: Private collection A.A. Tarpi, Dushambe, Tajikistan

summary: Three aurei; Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I.
Unknown original number of coins. 225 coins were known: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, four treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by three treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

The hoard comprised a double deposit within a single room of a building. In one corner of the room, there were four coins, including one of Marcus Aurelius, 1 of Lucilla and 2 of Commodus. In the opposite corner, there was an identical deposit.

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 63 coins were recovered, 62 denarii, 1 drachm: Vitellius – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
(circa 400) 22 denarii: 2 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 105-107)
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
(700) 612 silver coins: 610 denarii, 2 drachmas: Nero-Commodus (AD 184-185).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five denarii are known: Tiberius - Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).

Arm purse containing 63 coins (3 aurei and 60 denarii), ranging from the late Republic to Hadrian, found while quarrying stones. Each of the gold coins was wrapped up in a separate piece of greenish leather or vellum, which was still quite tough and strong.
disposition: Clayton Memorial Museum, Chesters (purse). The coins are said to have been given to the Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, but have not been located there

summary: 28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.
103 denari: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 262.8-420.7 g.
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 12 (103 coins).

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).
The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
disposition: L. Hamburger (British Museum); Montagu Collection; J. Evans; Kelsey Museum of Archaeology in Ann Arbor, Michigan; Detroit Institute of Arts

summary: A hoard of Roman aurei and their imitations was discovered in an earthen pot: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).
70 denarii: 69 Rome issues, 1 imitation: Trajan - Commodus (AD 187-188). Together, it was found a ring made of a silver-coloured metal.
A large hoard of 1,500-2,000 coins: 508 republican coins are identified; all the emperors up to Hadrian are represented except Augustus.
75 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
disposition: Museum of Southern Podlasie, Biała Podlaska, Poland

summary: 200-150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 48 denarii are known today: Nero – Hadrian (AD 125-128).
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.
22 bronze coins found together: Obol, prutahs, local, provincial issues: Ptolemy VIII Physcon - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
Group of 3 coins: Domitian denarius, Trajan denarius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
About 5000 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
41 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
64 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel, which was recovered in fragments and comprised 228 denarii. Part of the hoard (estimated at 58 coins) was sold but the landowner kept 200 or 201 denarii from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
Found during excavations, in an early medieval cemetery. Tomb 569B: inhumation, male; among grave goods 3 (?) Aes coins, part of the "Tascheninhalt".
188 bronze coins fund in a ceramic vessel: 151 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 4 dupondii/asses, 17 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).

The hoard comprised at least 227 silver coins: 119 Nabatean denarii, 14 provincial tetradrachms of Antioch, 5 didrachms reattributed to Antioch (Trajan), 5 tridrachms and 33 drachms of Trjan reattributed to an Arabian mint, and 51 imperial denarii, down to AD 122.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (108), Ecole Biblique, Amman Museum

summary: The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
64 denarii found in a wall of a glass workshop: Nerva - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
300 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
1600 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, bone artefacts.

A Roman arm purse was found on a field, southwest of Hahn (today in the district of Pfungstadt), in the vicinity of the Hofgut Grabenbruch. The purse contained 8 Roman denarii, ranging from Galba to Trajan.

The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.
(c. 3000-3500) 474 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins and 1 bronze coin dated to the second century AD.
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 235 were documented: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Weight: 597.2g (196 coins).
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (collection Iversen); University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (36 coins)

summary: Unknown number of aurei and silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only five aurei were seen: Trajan 4, Trajan for Plotina 1.

A mixed hoard of Syrian tetradrachms, Cypriote tetradrachms / didrachms, and denarii, ranging in date from Nero to Hadrian. One coin of Vespasian is countermarked by Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-180), which is why the closing reign is given here as Marcus Aurelius.
A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.

The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a stone figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular stone pediment and some carbonised cereals.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel. It comprised approximately 150 'large bronzes' likely to be sestertii. The hoard was discovered by a farm labourer on the plain of Saint-Rémy.
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
17 denarii: Titus - Hadrian (AD 117).
514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
At least 4 denarii found on a field: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I).
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.

The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.
16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: Hoard of nine aurei found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 3, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 4 (AD 177-178).
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 15 coins were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178). Kropotkin suspected that it may be the same hoard as Sosnitsa.
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (15 coins until 1917)

summary: (460) 452 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: M. Antony - Marcus aurelius (AD 176-180).
A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Split, Croatia; partly dispersed

summary: 4 asses found during excavations: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45373-45376

summary: Unknown original number of sestertii: Titus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Town museum, Kaliningrad, Russia (inv.no. КГОМ 1.18842/1-119); Archive Rudau (in 1911) (inv.no. Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_2, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-148_1, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_1)

summary: 22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
37 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No details on the structure.
Five denarii found during survey in small area. Interpreted as small disturbed hoard.

The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.
10 bronze coins found during archaeological excavations: 5 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 3 asses: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: History Museum, Svištov, Bulgaria; inv.nos OF 3583-3588; HCF, inv.no. 886-889

summary: The hoard comprised '27 aurei of Vespasian to Commodus along with some silver denarii.' The gold coins were distributed amongst the family of the landowner. Although 9 of the aurei were given to the Musée de Rouen by M. Esnault, these were later stolen.
disposition: Musée de Rouen, France (9 coins. stolen)

summary: 13 Roman silver coins, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, in 1781, all dug up 'with a great many more' in the muir (= moorland) of Linlithgow. These probably came from a find of 300, found in the Burrowmuir, deposited in an earthen urn.
Hoard of unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were bought: Trajan, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 4, Marcus Aurelius 2, Lucius Verus, Faustina II, Commodus 2.
7 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in a building from the military vicus.
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: 3 denarii: Titus, Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 148-149); silver weight: 7.90 g.

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken C contains seven of the 217 denarii.

3,997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in two stages: 939 in 1965, 3,058 in 1970. In total: 3,663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: 5, or possibly up to 8 aurei, from Nero to Diva Faustina I (AD 161). 5 aurei are listed here, and the other 3 ones (Bland/Loriot 343-5) are listed separately as single gold finds.
disposition: Harris Museum, Preston (part); Blackburn museum (2 coins)

summary: 27 bronze coins (Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius) found in an ash layer covered by a stone and interpreted as a votive deposit.
A small hoard of denarii (6+ specimens, Antoninus Pius - Pertinax), found in or around Apelstedt.

The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.

A hoard of four denarii (2 Domitian and 2 Trajan) was found during field-walking in the South Annexe of the fort at Newstead. The coins were recovered in a little roll, with possible traces of a copper/bronze container.

177 denarii with portraits of emperors from Vespasian to Trajan and two denarii of Mark Antony's 'legionary' series. The denarii were found with a ceramic vessel. The metal analyses, fresh minting loo-alike state of preservation for the large majority of the coins as well as the overweight for most of the coins reveal a 'hoard' of ancient counterfeited coins. The dating of coin type is based on the genuine prototype, otherwise, it looks that they were all minted in/after AD 116.
disposition: Museum of National Union, alba Iulia, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised at least 54 silver coins dated between the Roman Republic and Hadrian (AD 117-138).

In 1806, on the south-west side of Trinity Court, near the Turnpike Road, a hoard of nearly one hundred Roman coins was found. 79 of them were listed, ranging from the Republican period to Trajan. A few days after, a medal of Nero, and one of Antoninus Pius were found on the same spot. The Republican coins were certainly silver, but the metal of the others is uncertain.
Unknown number of aurei and denarii: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) (AD 145-161).
Hoard of 183 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
64 denarii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Three denarii: Republic 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 138-161).
Four 2nd c. AD coins were found during sharding in Flurdistrikt above the Geybach river.
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only six provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
Circa 150 denarii. 100 were studied: Hadrian - Pertinax (AD 193).

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and two dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
Unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania: Vespasian – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 2042-2059).

summary: 11 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 2 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-179)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coins), donations P. De Baeck.

summary: Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 10 denarii: Trajan – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162).
disposition: NPÚ-ÚOP Pardubice, Náchod Castle collection, Czech Republic (inv.nos. 2.920, 3.016-3.023).

summary: A hoard of ca. 460 Roman silver denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius for 344 of them, the others are lost), found in an earthenware container 1 1/2 feet under the soil while removing stones ('Steineroden') in the heather, at Wassermühle on the Wingstberg.
NA
This hoard was found in a Roman building. It consisted of 7 denarii, ranging from the late Republic to Antoninus Pius. The coins lay stratified in a roll and the find appears to be complete.
1,055 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (1,042 coins; inv.no. C 706); History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (8 coins); private collections (5 coins)

summary: 72 denarii: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. Six denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: Four coins of Bar Kochba (AD 132-136).

In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river two miles from the estuary. The six preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.
Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).

At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a tennis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that one of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, none of which were recovered. Four further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: (Cassandrea, Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia), found in grave 589 in Ierissos.
Two denarii found on a field: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 185).
Two aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.

A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180). Two other coins, one bronze and one bronze of the 4th century were handed together to the museum.
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
36 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111) found hidden in the wall of a Roman house.

168 Alexandrian provincial bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149). Found in the ground. All drachms, only briefly described. Oldest Vespasian, among the other coins are mentioned "interesting types of Antinous, Sabina, Aurelius Caesar, also some of the rare 'nome' types and few of the famous zodiacal series struck in the eighth year of Antoninus Pius."
735 denarii found with ceramic vessel and a textile bag: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 195). Found together with a silver T-brooch within a Sarmatian settlement.
disposition: Numismatic Collection of the Institute of Archeology, Iași, inv. no. 323370 (the brooch)

summary: The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised three asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
Heap of sestertii, 6: Trajan 4, Commodus 1, uncertain 1 (AD 180-192).
The hoard originally comprised 21 bronze coins found with an amphora: Vespasian-Antoninus Pius (73-145 AD). Only 18 coins are still available.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Iatly

summary: 110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver weight: 202.4-323.4 g.
160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.
135 denarii found by metal detecting: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). Together were found: Flint pendant; an iron chain; a ceramic spindle.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 304 coins were recovered together with the vessel's sherds: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver weight: 10.25 g.

The hoard originally comprised 1,305 Greek/Roman imperial/Roman provincial silver and bronze coins together with gold and silver ancient jewellery. Nowadays 1043 bronze coins and two couple gold earrings are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Shahat. According to the 1934 find report, the missing silver part featured 32 Greek silver coins (280-50 BC, including 16 coins from the Achaean League and four Rhodian drachms), 39 Roman imperial denarii and quinarii (Otho-Trajan, AD 69-116, mint of Rome) and 45 Roman provincial drachms and hemidrachms struck under Trajan (RPC III, 1-3, AD 100). These, as well as 89 sestertii, 77 dupondii, and 128 asses, were probably made in Rome for circulation in Cyrenaica.
14 Roman bronze coins and one autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Nine denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).
42 denarii, ranging from Nero to Didius Julianus. It is unsure whether three antoniniani (1 Gallienus, 2 Probus) and 1 denarius of Elagabalus were part of the hoard as well.
A large hoard of 2,218 coins: Vespasian - Commodus. No further information.
(c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).
Report in BM file with information from Suffolk county Council on a group of 7 or 8 coins, only three readily identifiable. Details of the latter only were received.
15 sestertii as a foundation offering: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
A hoard of unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Leather purse with 10 bronze rings and 11 bronze coins: Trajan - Antoninus Pius. Only one bronze coin of Antoninus Pius is known.
14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver weight: 38.41 g.
20 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only eight pieces were recovered: 2 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 3 asses: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
19 asses found within one square meters: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 177).

In 1925 a hoard comprising 1081 bronze coins, originally included in a pottery vessel, was found after agricoltural works. Coins inlcuded in this hoard returned to the finders and went missing, except for 1 sestertius of Didia Clara now kept in the Museum Bottacin in Padua. Only a brief report on the coins included in the hoard is now available.
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
Four coins found in Jülich, during the construction of the technology center.
At least 9 denarii and 1 aureus: Trajan-Hadrian (AD 117-138).
A hoard found in a field south of Castlethorpe, comprising 20 denarii and 35 bronze coins, up to Lucius Verus.
65 Roman silver coins found a small urn or earthern vessel, while removing the root of a tree near the house of Mr. Burke, at Beaconsfield. The coins ranged from Vespasian to Faustina.
50 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 137.84 g.
The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown number of aurei of the Anoninian house (the number expressed were between 5,000 and 9,000). Only one piece of Antoninus Pius was identified.

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Five denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).
A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
13 coins (10 provincial coins of Philippi, 2 denarii of Trajan and 1 imperial bronze of Domitian) found in grave T45 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
(200) 38 denarii: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
23 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: Museum of Dacian and Roman Civilisation, Deva, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised of 27 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. 26 are identified.
34 coins found by Caspar Reuvens in 1828: 2 denarii, 3 sestertii, 15 asses, 6 dupondii, 6 dupondius/as, others unclear: Nerva - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

West Parade site Area III, Roman interval tower. In late Roman period, interval tower became derelict, & much of upper part prob. demolished/ robbed. Lower part of tower infilled with demolition debris, incl. ceramic tile frags. & mortar, animal bone waste from food consumption, & bird & animal skeletons, incl. ravens & dogs, frogs & toads, & remains of owl pellets. 3 silver denarii in fine condition also found amongst demolition debris, of Trajan, Hadrian & Faustina, minted in early to mid 2nd C. before tower even built; & it is likely that they were hidden & subsequently lost, poss. as part of a larger hoard, whilst tower was still in use.Gilmour, B. 1999. Excavations. In C. Colyer, B.J.J. Gilmour & B. Jones The Defences of the Lower City. Excavations at The Park and West Parade 1970-2 and a Discussion of Other Sites Excavated up to 1994. The Archaeology of Lincoln VIII-2. CBA Res. Report 114, pp. 191.
Three aurei found at the bottom of "an old wall": Faustina I, Faustina II under Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar). The hoard was found by a farmer.
A hoard of 3-400 aurei. 42 coins were recovered. They are all issues of Lucius Verus, 3 types (Coh. 157, 247, 248).
disposition: Royal Coin Room, Amsterdam, Netherlands (3 coins since 1894); 1 coin in Berlin

summary: 15 aurei and 470 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Marcus Aurelius, found by a labourer at work in Rudchester grounds, while digging up the foundation of an old fence in 1766.

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: Hoard of 375 denarii. Only 7 coins were mentioned: Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Faustina II 3, Lucilla, Commode.
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
Hoard of circa 700 denarii. Only 350 pieces are known: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Hoard of circa 600-700 denarii. 433 pieces were studied: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: Around 350 denarii found in Duurzerdiep near Balloo. Only 85 denarii are known: Nero - Commodus (AD 180).
disposition: Drents Museum, Assen (84 coins), RMO, Leiden (4 coins), KPK, Leiden (1 coin); most disappeared PMD 84 coins; RMO 1 coin; [KPK 4 coins]; PMD: 80 coins: 58 in collection van der Feltz, 3 bought in 1871, 4 bought in 1873, 3 bought in 1881, 12 in the Frisian

summary: Over 1,000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
Unknown originally number of coins. 40 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
8 Roman bronze coins to Antoninus Pius plus 8 Durotrigan cast bronze coins
76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: 12 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Titus - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: Two sestertii found together and recorded as a hoard in the HER. The coins could not be closely identified and were returned to the finder as they did not meet the criteria for Treasure.
2 denarii of Hadrian
The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
112 bronze coins: 111 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
A hoard of denarii found at Brixworth, in 1892. It is complete except for one denarius of Antoninus Pius of uncertain reverse. Coins range from Vespasian to Crispina.
78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
20 sestertii and 1 as: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
(c. 260) 77 sestertii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 163-164)

The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. Three publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. One further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
Hoard found with an amphora: 2 aurei, 2,804 denarii, 2 bronzes: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). Together was found a ceramic lamp.
disposition: Private collections: A. Ancona,F. Gnecchi (365 coins), M. Anti (1,080 coins) (in 1887)

summary: Around 500 denarii. Only three are known from Domitian and Trajan.
disposition: Muzeum Archeologiczne i Etnograficzne w Łodzi, Poland (3 coins)

summary: Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Three denarii (Nerva - Faustina II), found with others on a field in Halsmühlen.
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
115 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 354 g
129 bronze coins (1 provincial) unknown denomination: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158)
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.

The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

Six silver coins minted in Caesarea of Cappadocia: Nerva, Trajan 2, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius. According to Pachomov they are coming from a destroyed burial ground. a plausible hypothesis as Kropotkin (2005) mentioned other similar coins found in graves (p. 267; nos. 1927, 1928, 1944).
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.no. 84974)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 145 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 178-191).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; private colection V. Heisu from Parava (145 coins)

summary: About 700 Roman coins were found in a ford in the river Pettarel near Carlisle in 1762. Coins seem to range from Nero to Faustina. A list of 64 of them (1 aureus, 62 denarii and 1 sestertius) exists.
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
Group of 5 coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) as, Claudius I as, Nero 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
Three denarii found on a field: Trajan 1, Lucilla 1, Faustina II/Lucilla 1

Over 300 denarii, only 8 coins were seen: Antoninus Pius 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II), Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla).
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Vespasian 1, Nerva 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I 1, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2429

summary: Hughenden - Upon Piggott Common: 24 Roman coins (copper) discovered 1795 in throwing up a bankan earthen vessel about 18 inches below the surface.
Seven aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).
Originally 312 denarii, 299 preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 758.24 g. (299 coins).
(ca. 900) 889 denarii: 46 republican, 843 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Found in two vessels.
disposition: Regional Museum of Russe, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1618 (889 coins)

summary: HER record of a hoard of 32 Roman copper coins, "chiefly of the Middle Empire" found in 1772 at North End in Turville. Eight of the coins were said in 1797 to be in the possession of Col Innes of Ibstone House, of which there were 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 "Faustinas", 2 "Vespasians", 1 Trajan and 1 "Aurelius". Source: Thomas Langley 1797 "History and Antiquities of the Hundred of Desborough" p.383.
Around 2,000 denarii found on the surface after the river outflow. Only 8 denarii were known: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Faustina I 3, Commodus 2.

A hoard of 180 denarii, ranging from Nero to Commodus. 9 denarii (Otho-Commodus) were found in 1938, on Lord Clyde's estate of Briglands, Rumbling Bridge. Subsequent discoveries at the same place were made in 1948-57, two-thirds of the way up the steep left (east) bank of the River Devon, after a coin was found at the opening of a rabbit hole. One further coin was reported in 1972.

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.

453 denarii from Nero to Commodus (AD 180). The latest coin has the reversed inscription as: TR P V IMP IIII COS II P P. The composition of the hoard is described by D. Tacchella (1896) by of number types not by the number of coins (!). There are 224 types: Nero 1, galba 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 21, Titus 4, Domitian 9, Nerva 4, Trajan 13, Hadrian 34, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 54, Faustina I 23, Marcus Aurelius 30, Faustina II 12, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 5, Commodus 1, Crispina 1.
disposition: Some of the coins entered the National Museum in Sofia in 1895.

summary: Two denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
21 denarii: Galba - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 14845-14865 - in 1944)

summary: 38 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 192).
15 sestertii, dupondii, asses: Augustus-Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
63 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: Sold; Local museum Olevsk, Ukraine (3 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 13 silver coins dated between AD 62/3 and AD 123.
21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.
378 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).

The hoard was found in a heap of stones without any obvious container and comprised 'some Roman gold coins. There is some debate over the number of coins found. According to Chassant, there were 5, but Leclerc de Pulligny suggests there was 'a multitude'. Pulligny also mentions a coin of Lucius Verus, but this is not recorded amongst the coins examined by Chassant. Found in a pile of stones with no obvious container.

In 1955 during ground work at a cemetery children randomly found a Roman hoard with a large quantity of coins. All coins except for the 10 described here (sestertii ranging from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) were dispersed. The true size of the hoard is unknown.
Four asses found during the excavations. To be checked whether were found together.
24 denarii found ina lump of earth: Domitian – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: 26 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 183).
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre d'entrée, II, p. 230, no. 12.428

summary: The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins: 999 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
disposition: Poltava Local History Museum (954 specimens; inv.nos. 4919-4920, 5090)

summary: The hoard comprised 100 Roman coins, including one of Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of 89 coins of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Eupator.
Grup of two denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161); silver weight: 5.52 g.
15 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Two denarii issued by Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-176) were bought from the same local person.
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).
A small hoard consisting of 15 bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to the reign of Marcus Aurelius was found in 'Haus V der Kiesgrube Lerpscher' during excavations in 1932.
10 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius) found corroded together with a bronze fibula and a clasp. They might have been contained in a purse.
The hoard comprised 45 silver tetradrachms from Claudius I to Antoninus Pius. It is not clear whether the coins represent a complete hoard or part of a hoard.

In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: 271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 268 handed to the National Museum in Bucharest: Nero - Marcus Aurelius. One denarius may depict Julia Domna?
disposition: National Museum of History, Bucharest, Romania; Museum of History and Archaeology, Piatra Neamț, Romania (the vessel)

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
The hoard comprised a 'vessel containing 60 aurei, of which 17 were bought by the Cabinet des Médailles and 2 by the Musée de Rouen, although neither acquisition can be found today.'

Unknown original number of coins. 184 denarii of which two imitations: Vespasian - Didius Julian (AD 193). Found together with a "belt set of one massive silver buckle for a sword belt and two buckles for a girdle. The find also contains eighty-four silver belt plaits. This belt set, dating to the latter half of the 5th century AD (phase D2 of the Great Migration Period), is a girdle for bladed weaponry."
disposition: The State Museum of Military History and Natural Preserve “The Kulikovo Polye”, Tula, Russia (inv.no. BX 1823/1-184)

summary: More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: A hoard of 161 aurei and 4 denarii was discovered on the site of 29 Klagenfurter Str. in Villach. Four aurei were initially discovered before a supervised excavation at the site uncovered the rest of the coins. Of the 161 aurei, only 100 issues dating from Nero to Septimius Severus have been properly catalogued. The four denarii have all been catalogued: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197).
disposition: Museum Der Stadt Villach (115 aurei and 4 denarii); private collection (42 aurei)

summary: A hoard of more than 3000 coins was found opposite the church in Baarlo in 1830. More than 3000 coins (32 gold and the rest in silver) remained with banker Wolters. Further data is missing. Description is known for 5 coins. The first publication, in 1838, mention coins from Augustus to the Antoninians.
Hoard of 800 denarii. Among them, three pieces of Pertinax
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
2 aurei: Nero, Antoninus Pius .
Four denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.
5 denarii from Vespasian (Domitian) to Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius). Part of a larger hoard, details unknown.
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 95 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Pertinax (AD 193).
1,300 Provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: . 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto.

summary: A hoard of an unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. 44 coins were recovered: Republic - Trajan (AD 102).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 157 coins found in a ceramic vessel: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
Unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins are known: Antoninus Pius 2, one of the Faustinas 1, Lucilla 1.
13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Hoard of at least 46 denarii: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoard from Strunga.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (25 coins)

summary: A deliberate deposit from the excavations at Ashwell. E Ghey writes: Group 2002 T215 (5) consisted of items in a 'placed deposit' in context 203. This deposit consisted of two copper alloy units of Tasciovanus, four copper alloy units of Cunobelin, one silver Icenian unit, a pierced dupondius of Claudius, an as of Vespasian and an as of Hadrian. The non-coin objects consisted of second century AD Roman objects (a brooch, mounts, numerous fragments of iron mail armour and implements, a fragment of a pipe-clay figurine) and part of a Bronze Age spearhead, in addition to fragments of pottery, animal bone and cremated bone. The as of Hadrian places deposit (5) in the second century AD at the earliest; a time in which the coin evidence as a whole suggests a reduction in activity at the site.
Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
15 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
disposition: Groninger Museum (12 coins), private collection (3 coins)

summary: Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only two of them were known: 1 Trajan, 1 Faustina II.

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included one denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: 237 coins: 11 denarii, 226 bronzes (most of them sestertii): Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
(180) 141 silver coins: 140 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm dating from the Republic to Trajan.
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (141 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver weight: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: The hoard comprised 117 sestertii and 43 dupondii or asses from Vespasian to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. It was found under the sixth step of a staircase discovered under a lime kiln.
Circa 100 Roman coins, silver and bronze. Only, 2 denarii of Antoninus Pius and Faustina I and 5 bronze coins (Vespasian to Trajan) were known.
Hoard of around 2,000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Initially 368 denarii, nowadays, 367: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 1009.47 g.
disposition: The National Historical Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 10155/1-167, 169-368); Stockholm Numismatic Institute, Stockholm (inv.no. 179)

summary: The hoard was found in a burial which contained 'two middle bronzes of "Antoninus" and one of Faustina II, as well as a unidentified sestertius.
The hoard comprised 5 drachms of Trajan minted in Bostra (AD 113).
10 coins. Unknown denominations: Augustus - Hadrianus (AD 117-138).
Unknown originally number of coins. 28 denarii are known: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 190-191).
The Cheshire HER lists "A small hoard comprising a silver denarius of Faustina II (AD 176), two unidentified Roman bronze coins and a bronze dolphin-type booch datable to 1st to 2nd century AD".
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins, dating between AD 79/80 and AD 119/120.
Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins and some bronzes, including one of Faustina I.
368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
Hoard of 11 denarii.

A hoard of ca. 639 Roman denarii, found in a 'crock' at Upwood Farm, near Handley, while digging up an allotment garden in 1877. A list of 571 coins (by emperor only, see NC 1950, pp. 311-312) was made by Dr. Blackmore who himself received 464 coins of the hoard. His list is as follows: Marcus Antonius 20, Nero 2, Galba 2, Otho 4, Vitellius 3, Vespasian 60, Titus 5, Domitian 31, Nerva 19, Trajan 55, Hadrian 78, Sabina 4, Aelius 4. Pius 79, Faustian I 44, Marcus Aurelius 63, Faustian II 23, Verus 14, Lucilla 13, Commodus 36, Crispina 5, Didius Iulianus 1, Severus 1, and Domna 1. What remains of these 464 coins is now preserved in the Dorchester Museum, but only 440 coins were catalogued by Roberston (NC 1950). These are all denarii (Mark Antony - Julia Domna), except for one Lycian drachm of Trajan.

72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in two concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. Two further coins were found nearby.
Three aurei of Hadrian. Only one was seen.
102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).
Two aurei of Vespasian and Trajan, probably, found in Braga.
The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.
22 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.
1,446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found two silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.

A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.
16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: 81 bronze coins (72 Dium, 3 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Philippi, 1 koinon of Thessaly, 3 Roman bronzes) ranging from Domitian to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the east wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1999 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard originally comprised ca. 1,750 Greek/Roman republican/imperial/provincial silver and bronze coins ranging from 270 BC to the reign of Trajan (116 AD). 570 of them are know kept in the Shahat Archaeological Museum while further 84 specimens have been identified through photographic documentation.
A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling two tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).

Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 27 coins provide information on issuers: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Seven aurei: Vespasian - Hadrian. No further information.

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by five treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by one of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and five fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 40 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. X

summary: A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
63 denarii found within the ruins of a Roman house: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161). The silver link found with the coins may suggest a bag as the container.

The hoard comprised 13 denarii from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus. They were found concealed in the belt of male burial interpreted as being that of a Roman soldier. The burial was found in the courtyard of a building situated at No. 12 rue des Fantasques
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as one block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD

A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in one lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.
Unknown originally number of coins. Six denarii of Marcus Aurelius were seen.

1,022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second one it was pretended to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just one hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: Hoard of at least 62 denarii. Only 13 are known: 8 republican among which Julius Caesar 1, Augustus 3, Hadrian 2.
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and one more denarius found in 2009. Most likely one owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
Funerary find: 2 aurei in a grave: Nero, Marcus Aurelius
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre des entrées, III, f. 114, nos. 3558-3559

summary: Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: "About 100 tetradrachms and denarii together with a few dozen Roman coins (the latest being a fresh Hadrianic denarius...)" (Mildenberg 1984, 55).
101 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175).
The hoard comprised approximately 15-20 tetradrachms and 70-80 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
55 billon drachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-155) found at floor level in a room during excavations of a house.
41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: A hoard of 2000+ silver coins (mainly Cappadocian didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms; two Lycian drachms; c.100 denarii) deposited c. 185 and found in four bronze pots in the village of Sor, near Kayseri. It was dispersed in several batches in the art trade. A large portion was published by W. Metcalf (932 coins) and another by W. Weiser (178 coins, the 'Münchner Fundkomplex'). In addition, 140 coins were recorded in Paris in 1980 (RPC III, p. 376). They consisted in 26 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), and 114 coins from Caesarea (Vespasian - Commodus)
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 10 pieces are known: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186-192).
29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found two gold fingerings.
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
149 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 147 imperial denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
Unknwon number of denarii found with an iron vessel. Only 14 denarii were identified: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) (AD 196-198).
180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
513 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102)
disposition: Museum of Art History, Vienna, Austria (1847)

summary: Circa 50 denarii, kept in a belt? 49 documented: Galba – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Museum, Prague, (inv.nos. H5-27.066–27.073); Museum of Poděbrady (inv.nos. 15.566–15.574, 15.576–15.577, 15.579–15.591) (inv.nos. 15.575, 15.578 were stolen), Czech Republic. Some of the coins are missing today.

summary: A potful of Roman silver coins. Only five coins have been poorly documented: L. Scribonius Libo, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina I, Faustina II, Commodus.
121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.
646 denarii layed in the ground: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). 152 coins of this find disappeared between 1907 and 1975.
Originally, 78 denarii, 14 preserved: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 189); silver weight: 36.63 g. (14 coins).

A hoard of 420 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius, found near Alma Wood, Londonthorpe, together with fragments of the base of a small grey flagon which judging from its size and the marks of corrosion on the inside had originally contained the whole hoard. –A.J. White, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 12 (1977), 81; 13 (1978), 85
disposition: British Museum (part); Lincoln City and County Museum (part); Belton Trust (part); rest returned to finder

summary: "1 litra" of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 2 denarii are known: Domitian, Trajan.
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warszaw (2 coins), Poland

summary: 26 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
10 denarii found within a cemetery together with other objects. The antoninianus (radiate) of Aurelian may be an intruder.
disposition: Initially in the collection of Councilor Scotti, later in the Museum of Wroclaw, Poland; today, lost.

summary: A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by seven treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the seven treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of one of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
8 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 191-192).
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 7 silver coins - 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 drachm - deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
