Twenty-two denarii found on an agricultural land: Otho - Commodus (AD 187-188).
Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: 13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: Four coins on PAS database centered to village - possibly a hoard or addenda to one of the previous hoards?Other PAS records associated with this hoard: CAM-531F17
2 Iron Age gold quarter-staters, 18 denarii and 1 quinarius to Antoninus Pius and 6 copper-alloy votive objects.
270 coins. Only 10 sestertii are known: Trajan, - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection vicar Verstraete, Kortrijk, Belgium (c. 155 coins), in 1846; collection .C. Lefèvre,Brugge, Belgium (10 coins), in 1846

summary: Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.
The hoard was found in April 1841, in an ceramic vessel under a stone. It comprised 140 sestertii, dupondii and 1 as, all from the antonine dynasty.
4 denarii up to Commodus found in an arm purse.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 20 denarii were documented: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina (AD 161-180).
Circa 60 aurei. Disintegrated cloth bag found during excavations in the courtyard of a house.
(50) 25 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found together with a silver bracelet.
17 silver and bronze coins in Principia/barrack: 1 denarius, 1 quinarius, 2 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 6 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-138)
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
Around 100 denarii, 27 were studied: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175).

Hoard of 36 coins (31 bronze and 6 silver) "from 76 BC to AD 180 or 270" found during Pitt Rivers' excavations at the settlement site of Woodcutts, Sixpenny Handley. Said to have been found with the remains of a bronze-mounted casket near a hearth, possibly within a house."... the discovery here, within an oblong area of ' depression ' and near a hearth, of the remains of a bronze-mounted ornamental casket, with glass, a silver spoon, a penannular brooch, etc., and 31 bronze and 6 silver coins, from Claudius I to Claudius II (268-70)". (Hawkes, C.F.C. 1947, 'Britons, Romans, and Saxons Round Salisbury and in Cranborne Chase: reviewing the excavations of General Pitt-Rivers, 1881-1898' Archaeological Journal 104, p.46).

Four denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found at Aitnock fort (an Iron Age fort), situated on the summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of the Rye stream at the south-west angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. The coins had been wrapped in some material and were found in a layer of occupation.
Three Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.
Around 600 denarii of which only 17 provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of 120 coins: 2 aurei, 118 denarii: Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museo de San Isidro, Los Orígenes de Madrid

summary: 826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.
Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian
Three denarii found in a funerary urn together with an amber bead and a wire link ring: Domitian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (Divus) (AD 180).
282 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 222 coins were recovered: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest (182 coins); Institute of Archaeology ”Vasile Pârvan”, Bucharest (40 coins)

summary: Around 800 denarii of wchich 189 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Three aurei are said to have been found by Landrat von Weyhe. These might be the remnants of a gold hoard. Apparently, there was another aureus found at the place.
556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.
49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
272 denarii: Tiberius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 813.04 g
disposition: Complexul Muzeal "Iulian Antonescu", Bacău, Romania; inv.nos. 7008-7236

summary: 8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
Grup of two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I); silver weight: 5.32 g.

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).

12 denarii, of which 10 plated, were found with a ceramic vessel in a garbage pit: Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 3, Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) 2, Marcus Aurelius 1, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1 (post AD 173-174).

1590 bronze coins (1452 Dium, 47 koinon of Thessaly, 39 koinon of Macedonia, 13 Thessalonica, 7 Philippi, 2 Edessa, 2 Corinth, 1 Amphipolis, 1 Magydus, 1 Tralleis, 10 uncertain, and 15 Roman bronzes), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).
200 bronze coins: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.
3200 silver coins found with bronze cauldron: 3197 denarii, 3 drachmas Lycia: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161) . 10.8 kg
disposition: Museum ”Dr. Molnár István”, Cristuru Secuiesc, Romania (1965)

summary: Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Three sestertii: Claudius I, Nero, Marcus Aurelius were offered to the Regional History Museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria

summary: Råmosen, the numerically largest denarii hoard in Denmark, was found in 1782. The hoard consists of 428 denarii. There are two lists of coins for the hoard; one lists the end coin as a Marcus Aurelius, but there are contemporary letters mentioning coins with a portrait of Crispina.
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
Unknown number of denarii. 933 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Silistra: Nero - M. Aurelius (AD 162-163).

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).

322 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 181-182). The hoard also includes silver and gold jewelry. Gold: 1 bracelet, 1 ring. Silver: 1 patera, 1 chain, 2 brooches, 1 necklace, 1 bracelet, 2 cups. All items were placed in a silver casket.
726 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 187-192).
Five denarii, from the reigns of Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, and Commodus, discovered in a garden in Berlin-Lichterfelde in 1919.
More than 80 gold coins were discovered as surface finds between 1830 and 1958: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only seven of the coins were described sufficiently well to be accurately identified.
30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: 408 denari found by metal detecting: Nero - Hadrian. No further detail.
The hoard was found in a void within a Roman wall and comprised 5 sestertii: 1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius, 1 Faustina II (AD 147-176).
95 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195).

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
32 bronze coins found glued to each other: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
Unknown originally number of aurei. Forty-five coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. Seventeen coins were studied in detail. Nine coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.

The hoard comprised 2,077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: 126 bronze coins:120 sestertii, 5 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD. Only 73 coins are kept in the museums' collections.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Stadt Museum Villach, Austria. (73 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
13 silver coins: 10 denari, 3 cistophori: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Found with traces of a textile bag.

A hoard of 12 Roman coins (apparently silver), found in 1755 while building a road from Taymouth to Glenquaich, near the crest of the hill. The same find (but described as 14 denarii) is recorded as having been found while digging the foundations of a tower near Taymouth. The coins are from the Antonine period, none later that Marcus Aurelius. No further details given.
It comprised 200 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Commodus (AD 180-192) found with a ceramic vessel.
Hoard of more than 200 denarii. Only 10 were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Pertinax (AD 193).
212 denarii found with a box: Nero - Septimius Severus (Cludius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Together were found 1 bronze box, 2 gold bracteates, 1 spiral rod and 1 gilt silver ring.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 5204 coins; 4877 objects)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just one hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
Only 4 sestertii are known: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Around 418 silver coins: 416 denarii, 2 drachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-180).
disposition: Muzeum, Koszalinie; Muzeum Zamojskie, Zamość; private collections, Poland

summary: Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.
(ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and four barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: The hoard comprised 171 aurei and 1 denarius from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
disposition: União de Bancos Portugueses. Fundação Millenium, Oporto, Romania

summary: A mixed hoard of 18 coins (Vitellius - Diva Faustina II) was unearthed in the southern area of the civilian town. The date of the latest coin is given as AD 145/161 in FMRD, but the reference of that coin (RIC 1383) is dated to AD 163-164.

A hoard of ca. 850 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found at Amheida (Dakhla/Dakhleh oasis) in area 4, divided in three textile bags, on top of a mudbrick debris layer filling pit F90, immedialely adjacent to the temple of Thoth.
The hoard comprised 144 silver and two gold coins dated between 32-31 BC and AD 124-128, buried in a clay juglet.
Hoard of uncertain number of imperial denarii found while metal detecting. 28 coins were presented to the museum: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
disposition: Grodno State Historical and Archaeological Museum, Belarus

summary: Discovered in 2007 in a field, near a village, between the village and the Lyasnaya river; the coins were scattered over an area of 500x100 m and had two large concentrations (two hoards?). Included at least 500 denarii, of which only 20 are available for study (Vespasian-Clodius Albinus). Information about the hoard in 2009 came to the archaeologist V. Belyavets, and in the spring of 2010 V. Sidarovich examined the place of the find. In the same field, other items were found: fragments of silver brooches, a gold brooch, a spearhead, a gold ring (?). Their relation with the hoard is doubtful (items from the settlement?)

A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and Totengraben.
16 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 107-110).
17 bronze coins: 3 dupondii, 15 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken B contains 53 of the 217 denarii.
1 silver + 4 bronze coins: (1st century -2nd century AD), Augustus - Commodus (AD 192) found during archaeological excavations.
237 provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144). Two sacks found in a house during excavations.
Originally, 222 coins. 133 denarii are documented: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Iron Gates Museum, Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (122 coins); inv.no. 562-683; private collection, Bucharest, Romania. (11 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: 21 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
Forty-eight Roman denarii were found with a ceramic vessel in the rubble of a Sarmatian house in 1995 in the area of ​​an Avar burial ground in Hetényegyháza.
7 asses: Domitianus - Hadrianus (AD 121-122).
171 coins: 169 denarii,1 sestertius, 1 dupondius: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
disposition: Balaton Museum, Keszthely (91 coins); private collection (72 coins), Hungary

summary: 278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: Six aurei found in grave of Asfagur: Titus, Trajan, Hadrian 4 (AD 117-138).
Unknown originally number of coins. 68 denarii are kept in the collection of the Library of the Romanian Academy: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 29069-29136)

summary: Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
300 denarii, found with a ceramic vessel 237 coins were recovered: Otho – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (227 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (10 coins; inv.no. 361)

summary: Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.

Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
c. 800 aurei: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192). No further information given.
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.
Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius.

A hoard of denarii, found in an earthenware container, together with three silver bracelets, during the construction of the road from Kindelbrück to Weißensee, under an area of arable land. The content of the hoard was dispersed, but it could have amounted to more than 230 denarii.
154 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: According to W. Łonak, the coins were kept by the Provincial Heritage Department for Cultural-Historical Soil Alterations in Racibórz.

summary: Ten denarii (Vespasian - Commodus), found in 1872 during peat digging. Two thereof arrived in the Oldenburg archive; an additional three were noted in 1905 in private possession.
It comprised c. 500 denarii found with a vessel:Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
20 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191).
A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat stone.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 79 coins: 6 denarii, 45 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 12 asses found with shreds from the ceramic vessel: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them two imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).
The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.
10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.

9 denarii (Vespasian to Trajan) found among the infill of a trench carrying a conduit to service latrines in Building B, outside the north-western corner of the fort. Wheeler (1927) dated the infill (and therefore the construction of the conduit) by the date of the latest coin, arguing that its fine condition supported a deposition soon after its issue around AD 120. Simpson (1967) agreed that the hoard must have been deposited at about this time, but added that the accompanying pottery indicated the conduit and trench belonged to the later second or third centuries. The hoard, therefore, is likely to have been disturbed and moved from its original place of burial among the soil and other waste material used to fill the trench.
72 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
The hoard comprised 301 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 300 were of Nero with a single coin of Hadrian. They were acquired in Egypt by Dattari.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 200 coins. 13 were shown to the local archaeological society: 6 were 'frustes', 6 of the Antonine family (including Faustina I and II) and one depicted a wolf. Bizeul states that they were all coins of the High Empire. Sanquer suggested that the coin depicting a wolf was a fourth century nummus, but reverse types of the Antonine period also depict the wolf. The three coins of Antoninus Pius and 2 of Faustina given to the museum by Gauja 'found in Rezé in 1851' are likely to come from this hoard. The hoard was found during the building of the east-west road through the city.
(25) 15 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 426

summary: 6 denarii, probably, part of a larger hoard: Antoninus Pius 3, Faustina I (Diva) 1, Antoninus Pius (Divus) 2

Penhallurick 2009, 269: "The museum on St Mary's has three sestertii found in a midden layer on the southern shoreline of Tean in 1956. Accompanying pottery indicated an occupation from the first to the fourth centuries and included sherds of samian ware and a bronze brooch (Thomas 1985, p.183)". He notes that the second sestertius of Marcus Aurelius listed here may have been turned into a brooch (bronze adhered to the bottom of the reverse), though this has not been verified.
(c. 40) 27 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
disposition: Muzeul Naţional de Etnografie şi Istorie Naturală; Inv. 18.494/AR 6.698-6.724, N 6.110; acquisition document 86/22.05.1986.

summary: Hoard consists of 70 Roman denarii (26 studied, 1 solidus): Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Together with these coins were found: a solidus of Constantius II (Nicomedia/Cyzicus/Antioch, AD 340-355) as a pendant, two gold pendants slightly different in size, two belt buckles: one silver and one bronze, and a group of 13 silver pendants from a necklace.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 7 sestertiiare known: Trajan - Commodus (AD 181).
The hoard comprised a few tetradrachms and approximately 50 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
200 aurei, only 6 were available for study: Galba, Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus.
90 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
(21) 19 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Trajan - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
Hoard of 200 bronze coins: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised 60 silver coins from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian, deposited during the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-136). These coins were: 42 denarii (Vespasian to Hadrian), 10 tetradrachms and 1 tridrachm from Antioch (Nero to Trajan), 6 tridrachms and 1 drachm of Trajan from Arabia.
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
Six gold Roman coins found in a burial: Vespasian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 4.
Group of 3 Roman coins: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II) dupondius (AD 161-180).
7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: Over 600 sestertii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 5 sestertii, dupondii or asses from Tiberius to Commodus and was found in association with a key handle, an incense burner, two statues (one being of Mercury) and a statue base. The remains of a Roman building, the function of which was undetermined, was found close by.

A hoard of 59 plated Roman silver coins (cistophori and denarii), found on the south slope of the Acropolis in excavations by the Greek Archaeological Service, near the central room of the Eastern Roman cistern. Of the 59 coins, 35 could be identified: 16 cistophoric tetradrachms (Claudius – Nerva) and 19 denarii (Trajan – Commodus).
A hoard of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), found in a megalithic grave in an urn also containing ashes. The grave was located 20 m away from the mansion of Fickmühlen.
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
16 coins of Hadrian (AD 117-138). No further information.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.
Large number of silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. The minting period run from 91 BC to AD 254. Only 69 coins are preserved: 1 aureus, 66 denarii, 2 drachms: Republic to Hadrian (AD 119-122).
50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: (8-900) 52 aurei: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 172-175).
disposition: Collection Rockox (37 coins), in 17th century; collection Van Gestel (1 coin), in 17th century; collection Christine de Suède (non-identifiable)

summary: Four denarii, pressumably belonging to a hoard, found at the same place at different dates. ”The scientific literature has falsely perpetuated the locality of Mircești (situated 5 km to the west) as the place of origin for the coins.”

Lake Borresø surrounds the medieval castle of Lilleborg. During the draining of the lake in 1832 a mixed gold- and silver hoard was found. "Some" gold fingerrings, of which only one was recovered, and "several" denarii, of which sixteen were handed over to the later National Museum, were found "as if packed into something which had now disappeared".
166 bronze coins: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo, Spain

summary: 7 sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian (Sabina) 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) 2, Marcus Aurelius 2 (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised '100s of bronze coins (150 coins according to Angot). The majority were of Trajan, Hadrian and of Antoninus Pius. In the 1860s, the vicar of Fougerolles, Charles Pointeau, examined 72 coins and Chevallier acquired 'a good number, all large bronzes of Trajan to Commodus'. It has therefore been assumed that this hoard was made up of sestertii.
46 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).

Towards the end of October 1878 three aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A fourth aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.
2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: 40 denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Majority belongs to Hadrian.
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).
The hoard comprised 25 coins (23 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 Provincial bronze of Trajan of the Koinon of Cyprus), ranging from Titus to Antoninus Pius.
Seven denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).

A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Olten by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.

Four gold coins found in a stone sarcophagus during excavations: Vespasian, Titus, Hadrian 2. Together were found four denarii: Augustus, Trajan, Hadrian, Faustina I. Together were found gold and silver jewellery, vessels, glass objects.
3 denarii (Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).

A small hoard of six Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about two years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in two years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as one deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).
Some aurei. Only five are presented from Nero to Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar).
The hoard comprised between 150 and 175 bronze coins 'mostly of the Early Empire'. One coin bears the effigy of Faustina II

During the excavation of the native British site at Hengistbury Head, over 3000 coins were found lying on the surface and all through the soil. They had evidently been deposited in bundles. Of these over 100 were Roman, the earliest about 91 BC and the latest six coins of Antoninus Pius (138-61 AD). The rest were all British, consisting approximately of 1,300 of the Hengistbury cast type. Of the south-western struck type there were about 1,660. The remainder were various Gaulish, British and Channel Island types with a few new varieties. A coin with EISV on it was the only inscribed specimen.
disposition: British Museum (part); Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Museum (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: (8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)
15 coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to NUMIS the tpq is around AD 180.
Around 50 bronze coins were found in a money-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: Initially were found 81 coins. 44 coins: 1 cistophorus, 1 sestertius, 9 asses, 33 unknown bronze denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Arheoloski Muzej Istre, Pula, Croatia (44 coins); othewise dispersed

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.
The hoard comprised 461 bronze coins, including 4 dupondii and asses and 457 sestertii of Galba to Marcus Aurelius, with a tpq of AD 172 to 173.
Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only two coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.

Unknown originally number of coins. 10 denarii entered the collection of the Center for the Social Sciences in Craiova: Vitellius 1, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) 2, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1.
disposition: Center for the Social Sciences, Craiova, Romania

summary: Unknown originally number of coins, around 160-200 denarii. Only 90 were documented: Otho - Clodius Albinus (AD 195-197).
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.
Hoard of circa 86-87 aurei found with a ceramic vessel with a graffiti "IRENE": Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Circa 30 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197). Near the denarii, a silver "pendant" was found, a piece of a brown object of unspecified utility, coins from the 15th to the 20th century and sherds of pottery (probably modern). The coins from the hoard were identified based on poor or very poor quality photos.
The hoard comprises a small greyware vessel containing 12 denarii of one of the Faustinas.
74 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard was found in an ancient vessel and comprised between 500 and 600 bronze coins. Very close by, a large glass urn, pottery and three bronze basins were also found.
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).
Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6197-6234 (38 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 9 coins were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190). One nummus of Constantine I can be considered as an intruder.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Warsaw, Poland (donation R. Turkievich, 1936 )

summary: 2 denarii: Commodus, 1 imitation of Marcus Aurelius; silver weight: 5.06 g.
Hoard of 49 coins and jewelry was found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Jewelry: bronze loop, bronze buckle, silver buckle, 7 silver rings, 39 pearls of amber, coral, glass.
disposition: Local history museum Cherkasy, Ukraine (inv.no. 190092 - vanished in 1941-1945)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 100 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. Only 7 were examined: Nero, Vespasian, Trajan 2, Hadrian 3.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain (7 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a well. It contained 57 aurei including issues of Nero, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina). The coins were accompanied by 3 ceramic vessels, fragments of fineware pottery, 4 terracotta models in the form of portrait busts and a further figurine in the form of a miniature goddess in a biga.
The hoard comprised 86 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, although the author proposes a deposition date in the reign of Postumus.

A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: The coins were found in 1938/39 during excavation works on the west wall in the region of Geilenkirchen-Linnich (Kreis Jülich). 14 of the coins were lost. The remaining 21 ones are sestertii, ranging from Trajan to Commodus. All are very worn.
The hoard comprised 53 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Fifty bronze coins were discovered in Roux, but only 9 were preserved, ranging in date from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius.
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
Unknown number of denarii found in two small ceramic vessels placed 100 m from each other. 38 pieces are known from one of the vessels: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 44-81

summary: Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 13 silver and bronze coins deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.

The hoard comprised 60kg of sestertii mixed with some middle bronzes (2,500-3000 coins). Only 26 sestertii and 1 dupondius were preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 98-117). The hoard was found by a worker, planting a vineyard.
disposition: History Museum, Louresse-Rochemenier, France (10 coins); finder (17 coins)

summary: "In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including one of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. Two of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
Two aurei were found on the banks of the Paleru river.
37 sestertii found during rescue excavations. 32 coins were found in a ceramic jug and 5 next to it: Vespasian - Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius) (AD 180).
85 denarii: Nerva - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
92 silver coins, 90 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175); weight: 292.04 g.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra Neamț, Romania (inv.nos. 28530-

summary: A cultic area with two temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. One of the two temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
Unknown number of initial coins. 20 pieces - unknown metal - are kept in the Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (Ad 138-161).
disposition: Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).

The hoard comprised numerous copper-alloy vessels, a mirror, a folding seat, Samian ware cups and plates and six glass bottles, one of which contained 40 very worn sestertii and dupondii of Nerva, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
5 coins found scattered near a disturbed grave within a cremation necropolis: Hadrian 1 as, Antoninus Pius 4 sestertii (AD 152-153).
14 denarii found with ceramic vessel of which only 5 are known today: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Hadrian (Antoninus Pius Caesar) 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 140-143).
11 denarii found on the same field: Caesar – Vespasian (AD 69-79).

A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during six trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Four aurei (Nero to Antoninus Pius) recorded at 4 different points in time, between 1996 and 2002, clearly forming a hoard. Many other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval.
A hoard of 304 silver coins (303 denarii and 1 drachm), ranging from Nero to Commodus, found in summer 2019 (with 6 additional coins found in 2020) on the Adlerberg, near Pratteln.
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: 52 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 135.15 g.
The coins were found together, in a burnt layer 25 cm deep under Plattenstraße at Ritona.
11 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which one coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of two Roman querns.
The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. One of them belongs to Faustina I and one to Lucilla.
Unknown originally number of coins. 43 denarii are kept at the town museum in Piatra Neamț, Romania: Republic – Antoninus Pius (AD 147-148).
disposition: Town museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (43 coins)

summary: 220 denarii: Republican (163), Imperial (57); Republican - Antoninus Pius (AD post 141)
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (49 coins)

summary: 10 denarii found on a field: Trajan - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 26.87 g.
c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: 240 silver coins: 228 denarii, 2 drahms found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 8

summary: In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.
The hoard comprised approximately 40 tetradrachms and 150 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).
Two aurei depicting Lucius Verus (AD 161-169). No description. Callu-Loriot record these coins as single finds, however, same findspot, same coin issuer (quite rare).
5 sestertii ranging from Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 173-174). Part of a larger hoard.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5 coins; dispersed.

summary: Unknown number of denarii. There is information on four coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).
Hoard of around 100 denarii from the time of the Antonine dynasty. Only four coins are documented.

A number (possibly 150) of Roman silver coins (possibly Nero - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius), found in the vicinity of the Herren-Holz, a quarter of an hour north of Spahn, lying on a mound of earth.
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Originally were 108 denarii. Nowadays, 80 coins: Otho - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 215.80 g. (80 coins). Found in a domestic building with bones fragments and an oval whetstone.

The hoard comprised a total of 1,133 coins, including 1,031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in three layered rolls. They have been lost.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found four silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: 52 denarii of Hadrian of only three RIC types: RIC 119, 256, 339 (AD 134-138). Found together with some bits of amber.
A hoard of 12 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) was found during the archaeological excavation of a building thought to be a granary and comprised of thirteen Denarii coins.

Two groups of coins, discovered in May 1989 while metal detecting on building ground at Elphinstone Road, Hastings. The first group of coins (92 bronze coins, Nero - Hadrian) were found with the remains of a pot and the second group (52 denarii found 'in a lump', with 7 later addenda, Republic - Hadrian) was about 40 to 50 feet away from the first. This may suggest successive deposits but they were treated as one find at the time. They have been split here. This record is for the silver coins.
70 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
A Regensburg employee submitted 8 sestertii (Antoninus Pius to Commodus) to the prehistorical state collection. The coins were derived from a find of unknown size in Regensburg.
68 coins: 67 denarii, 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196). Weight: 156 g.
The hoard comprised 112 sestertii: Trajan-Septimius Severus (98-196 AD).
The hoard comprised between 1,400 and 1,500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised more than a hundred copper alloy coins of Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Commodus.

The hoard discovered no later than 1900; the total number of coins is unknown. A city dweller with the surname Shapiro bought 44 coins (Vespasian-Commodus; total weight 127.43 g), of which only eight were identified in the Imperial Archaeological Commission (by E. Pridik) and then were returned to the owner.
1 dupondius and 6 asses (Vespasian to Trajan) discovered beneath the concrete bedding for the flagstones at the south-eastern end of the basilica.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including one plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
A hoard of denarii, found in a field from 1962 until 2001. FMRD lists 67 coins (Trajan - Pertinax).
700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
During the excavation of the Sanctuary in Insula 20 of Colonia Ulpia Traiana, 6 coins were found deposited under wall plaster. The latest coins date to the period AD 103 to 111.
The hoard was found on the West of "Blanche-Fontaine" district. A worker discovered an amphora with 1000 aurei, only 164 are now recorded from Augustus to Hadrian.
7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: 151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.
Group of six denarii found on the same area of an ancient settlement (?): Mark Antony - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161/post). Similar structure with RATENICE 2002

A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
55 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Galba - Commodus (AD 189). Found one meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 2, practically, one hoard.
(1006) 978 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
46 bronze coins: 45 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2287-2326

summary: The hoard comprised 20 denarii from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192) and was found inside an ostrich egg.

A hoard of about 400 Roman silver coins, found at Torfoot, 7 miles south-west of Strathaven, in a glass bottle, while cleaning a drain. Coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, wife of Antoninus, Crispina, wife of Commodus, and various other Emperors and Empresses, &c., all in good preservation, are mentioned. About fifty of the coins were so much verdigreated and adhering together, that they were broken with a hammer by a rude and unskillful hand, in order to separate them. J. Lindsay, View of the Coinage of Scotland (1845), 265, added Hadrian, Marcus, Caesar, Pompey and Crassus to the list of emperors etc. represented. The three last names may have been due to a misunderstanding of the legends on some coins. True Republican den. would be unusual in a hoard as late as the reign of Commodus.

199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not one hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.
Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver weight: 194 g.
Hoard of didrachms and drachms of the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. 8 coins have been purchased by the local museum in Zugdidi: 5 didrachms Trajan, 2 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Trajan.
Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).

The hoard was found buried under a small heap of stones and comprised 22 bronze coins. Of these coins, 11 were identified as dupondii or asses of particular emperors. The others were not identified with any certainty, but were 'more or less recognisable' as issues of Vespasian or Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.

295 denarii and 2 sestertii (Mark Antony to Commodus) found on the latest floor level of Room 37. The coins were corroded together and no trace of a container was recovered. It is possible that 6 denarii presented to the British Museum in January 1930 by the Caerleon Excavation Committee may have come from this hoard (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Jan. 1930: Vespasian, 1; Hadrian, 3; Antoninus Pius, 1; Commodus, 1).
The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 117-138.

find_spot_name: CASTELNUOVO VAL DI CECINA - SAN BERNARDINO
summary: 102 coins found with the remains of a textile bag: 94 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Galba - Trajan (AD 112-114).
310 denarii found with two leather bags placed in a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 1996-2000 hoard: Nero - Pertinax (AD 193).
The hoard comprised a large number of silver denarii of Clodius Albinus (approximately 15 pounds in weight or 2,000 pieces).
84 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel; Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); weight: 281 g.
disposition: Muzeului de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra-Neamț, Romania

summary: 30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
Denarius hoard consisting of 14 denarii found with metal detectoring. Galba to Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of around 1,600 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 573 coins were documented: Titus - Septimius Severus Severus (AD 193-211).

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.
2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Unknown number of denarii. Only two of them are known: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla (AD 161-180).
2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
The hoard comprised more than 400 worn coins including issues of Nero, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Crispina.
7 coins found at 30 cm deep: 2 sestertii, 5 asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
47 denarii: Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193); silver weight: 87.1-137.5 g
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .
8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
1,268 coins: 7 aurei, 1,261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total weight: 4,023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) two ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.
3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).

The hoard was found at a natural spring and comprised votives (including numerous wooden statuettes) as well as '149 copper coins of Roman emprors'. 79 of these coins were identified. The others were illegible.
A hoard of 30 Roman silver denarii, found at Waddow Hall, Waddington, and declared Treasure Trove. All the coins with the Lancashire Museums Service
666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
15 AE to AD 195.
24 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I to Commodus (AD 180-183).
91 tetradrachms of Alexandria in a small pot found during excavations. Range: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: 12 in London, 5 in Oxford. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 2 aurei of Domitian and Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
119 Alexandrian billon tetradrachms: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156) Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935), inv.no. 445

summary: 14 coins ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (1 denarius of Trajan; 11 provincial coins: Dium, Koinon of Macedonia, Stobi; 2 uncertain), found in grave 5 in Sevasti.
(?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)
1000 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - in an ancient building. The latest coins belong to Antoninus Pius.
(10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Unknown initial number of denarii. Sixty-three coins were seen in the collection of the Friends of sciences Society Collection in Poznań: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Friends of sciences Society Collection, Poznań, Poland (63 coins)

summary: HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
20 denarii, 15 studied: Trajan – Commodus (AD 189).
A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.
272 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 119-122).
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. According to some incriptions the issuers were Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (ANTONINVS PIVS, ANTONINVS ARMENIACVS). Six or eight denarii were noticed.

Hoard of 39 denarii, 26 glass and amber beads, several fragmentary specimens, and fragments of metal ornaments, including two silver brooches: Vespasian - Commodus. "Denarii are dated to the second half of the 1st century – the end of 2nd century AD, dating of the brooches, however, indicates that the hoard was deposited in the second half of the 5th century AD."
85 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel within a burial ground of the Wielbark Culture: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 184).
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only for 7 cois is given Information on the issuers: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 172-192).
The hoard comprised 96 bronze coins from the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).
Some 650 provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150). 'Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina monetaria".
41 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) (AD 161)

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 34 bronze coins: 21 sestertii, 13 dupondii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.
14 silver and bronze coins of unknown denominations: Republic - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 145-176).
The hoard comprised 514 imperial bronze coins: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Altino, Italy; private collection; some lost

summary: A hoard of 427 silver coins (426 denarii and one Lycian drachm), of which the first lot was found in 1910 in a clay pot, while ploughing a field. It comprised 367 Roman denarii (Nero to Commodus), one Lycian drachm of Trajan and one contemporary cast forgery, also from Trajan. A further lot of 50 denarii (Mark Antony – Commodus) was found between April and December 1988 by members of the Chesterfield Metal Detector Club, in the vicinity of the first lot and can be regarded as a further portion of the same find. A further 8 denarii (Vitellius - Antoninus Pius) were found with the aid of metal detectors in November 2012.
disposition: Doncaster Museum (part); Newark Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 16 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.
The hoard comprised 4 aurei and 132 silver coins, as well as jewellery from the second century AD: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Associated with Bar Kochba revolt (AD 132-135).
Over 600 bronze coins found with ceramic vessel. Only 11 pieces are recorded: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 163-164).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueología e Etnología, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: Around 800 denarii, among them issues of Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius.

The hoard comprised 116 silver coins: 111 denarii, 1 denarius serratus, 2 quinarii, 2 drachms: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158). Found in a ceramic vessel with a terra sigillata bowl serving as a lid.
Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
47 de denarii with very poor information on the contents: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)

A large hoard of gold coins (ca. 8 kg), found 40 km south of Mardin in 1890. Gnecchi also reports gold ingots, though Regling doubts this. The hoard was dispersed, but 302 aurei (Nero - Marcus Aurelius) have been published by Regling.

The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.
IARCH record for a hoard of 14 denarii. For further details and images see WMID-01F18E. Unpublished catalogue by Richard Abdy.

129 bronze coins (120 Dium, 4 koinon of Thessaly, 2 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Ilium and 1 uncertain), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 1999). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
(50-60) 13 bronze coins: 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-155).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (13 coins), in 1808

summary: 62 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 127-128)
(ca.30) 12 sestertii and dupondii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; auxiliary fund, inv.no. 693

summary: 9 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-130).
13 denarii found with a money-box: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-154).
26 denarii found in three separate finds (1921, 1924, and 1946): Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
Over 361 silver and bronze coins were found in five ceramic vessels. Only 191 coins were documented: 157 sestertii, 24 denarii were studied: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any one took the trouble to pick them up."
Six denarii found together on a floor of a Roman edifice from the Dacian kingdom capital of Sarmizegetusa Regia Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102).
disposition: Muzeul Civilizației Dacice și Romane, Deva, Romania

summary: 86 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156).
83 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
(200) 17 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 11-180).

From information obtained by Khaled Ben Rhomdane, the hoard comprised 2000 Republican denarii, although there is some suggestion that there were also imperial denarii including issues of Antoninus Pius. The hoard was stolen.
Hoard of 31 denarii. Only one denarius of Antoninus Pius is known.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei from Antoninus Pius to Marcus Aurelius.
324 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).
The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.

A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). Eight coins have been lost.
Three coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trustworthy and the coins are not preserved.
Circa 500 denarii, of which 264 were brought after 1873 to the National Hungarian Museum in Budapest. 168 coins were identified: Nero – Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-161).
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 30 bronze coins of Antoninus Pius. A bronze bell was found at the same findspot.
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins and 3 silver coins dated between the reigns of Vespasian and Hadrian.
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are two denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: 25 coins? "Medium-sized hoard. Allegedly Bar Kokhba silver and bronze together with Syrian tetradrachms and Roman denarii" (Mildenberg 1984, 56).

disposition: County Museum of Bistrița-Năsăud, Bistrița, Romania; Inv.no. MB 20918-20950

summary: Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 coins provide information on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
30 denarii: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). Found near the Roman villa.
270 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 183-184).
35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).
Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only two coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: A hoard of about a 100 Roman bronze coins, found on the estate of Carstairs house (= Monteith House). Nero, Trajan, Faustina, Germanicus, M. Aurelius, M. Antoninus are mentioned. To this hoard belonged 13 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781 (Trajan, Hadrian, the Empress Faustina, and Germanicus, are mentioned; the coin with Germanicus probably refers to an emperor Germanicus in its titles, e.g. Nero, Domitian or Trajan). No coins from this hoard have been located in NMAS, Edinburgh, or in Hunterian Museum, Glasgow. There is, however, in the University archives a letter from Mr. W. Fullerton, Carstairs House, dated 20 Oct. 1781, to Dr. A. Stevenson stating: "I send you a small box containing a dozen or more bronze medals intended for the College. About a hundred or more of them were found together by some workmen in repairing a road to a miln near this place [i.e. Carstairs House]. {...} They are cheifly [sic] Trajans Hadrian Antoninus Pius two or three Faustinas and one Marcus Aurelius Caesar and several others which from the inscription being much worn out their age cannot be so easily ascertained tho' on comparing them with Vallaint's [Vaillant's] Numismata they seem to be of Domitian. The place where they were found is about a quarter of a mile from an old Roman encampment or station [i.e. the Roman fort at Castledykes] of which part of the vallum remains still partly intire."
35 denarii found among stones: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only two coins are preserved
Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only two pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.

45 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Examined and photographed December 1962 in Athens by Hackens at a dealer of antiquities, who reported the hoard to have been found near Aswan.'
Four bronze coins, three sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)
112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
150 denarii. 145 coins entered the History Museum in Svishtov: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150); silver weight of c. 275.8-468.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1614-1735 (145 coins)

summary: 31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian

Over 40 Roman bronze coins, nummi of the Constantius II and the Houses of Valentinian I and of Theodosius I. Unearthed in 1888 by villagers digging a grave. No further details were reported. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissioner, was able to secure 40 pieces. The coin types were: Constantius II: fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Valentinian I: concordia auggg (Roma or Constantinopolis). House of Theodosius: salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); gloria Romanorum (two emperors).
102 sestertii, 5 dupondii and 1 as ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180). Hoard was originally larger.
A hoard of 296 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius), found by a grave-digger in Allerton Bywater churchyard.
Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard of 126 gold aurei contained within the fragmentary remains of a small pot was discovered while searching with a metal detector on land near Didcot, Oxfordshire, in April 1995. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius Caesar.

The Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale acquired 36 aurei on 17.03.1847 (Reg. C, nos. 1982-2017) and a further 44 on 8.2.1848 (Reg. C, nos. 2117-2160). 79 remain (with one swopped in 1939). The Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers bought 6 aurei on 3.4.1847 and 2 on the 13.06.1847, with fragments of the vase acquired on 04.03.1849 (Reg. I, p. 53-54, no. 209, p. 58, no. 217, p. 74, no. 269). They were stolen in March 1885.
105 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
23 denarii found with a money-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)

summary: Originally 390, 371 preserved: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 965.17 g.

A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot nine more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold one by one at the Violity auction.
The hoard comprised six bronze coins dated between AD 70-81 and AD 117/118. It was deposited inside the hollow part of a door frame in the tepidarium of a Roman bathhouse. Votive role?
12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).
Originally 5 denarii, 1 preserved: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186). Found together with 1 gold finger ring, 3 silver finger rings.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 52 denarii were found with a hand-made ceramic vessel: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

(?) 3 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
(Unknown initial number of coins, 5.76 kg): 367 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
6 denarii to AD 161 - "hoard 2" Davies 2000. From an occupation layer in range 3 of structure 1, Pickfords Garage site. Scattered in a small area with no evidence of a container.
The coins were found in a glass urn along with a human cremation. Among issuers Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).
Hoard of 87 aurei: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.
Hoard of 89 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I - 3, Cotys II - 6, Rhoemetalkes - 11, Eupator - 69.
The hoard apparently comprised 68 denarii, although the catalogue gives a total of 59 coins.
Over 60 denarii found on a field during 19th-21st centuries: Vespasian - septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

15 Roman gold coins described in the Madras Museum Accessions Register as 'purchases through individuals through the Collector of Canara'. It is unclear whether rhey represent a genuine hoard. Possible part of the cache of Roman coins dating from the first and second centuries A.D. was reportedly discovered some 600 kms. further to the north, on Kadmat Island in the neighbouring Laccadives group (Indian Union Territory of Lakshadweep) during 1948

Grup of three denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.
In 1908, 6 denarii (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found lying together at the entrance of cellar 208 (in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort).
A hoard of Roman denarii comprising at least 47 coins ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
Unknown originally number of coins. 11 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).

Seven denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.

A hoard of approximately 100 sestertii, dupondii and asses (Augustus - Commodus), found 500 m east of the village of Allaman, while digging the ground to install phone cables. 58 coins are preserved today (= ca. 60% of the hoard). The coins were heavily worn.

A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.

A hoard of 32 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) was found in April 2018 in Cherkassy region. Information about the hoard was published in three videos on YouTube, in the channel “Aleksander Mercedes w poiske klada”. The hoard was discovered by a group of treasure hunters on April 20, 2018 on ploughed field, at a depth of up to 15 cm. 21 coins and half of a bronze bracelet were collected from the surface of ca. 10-15 square m (the main concentration, 12 coins, in an area of 5x5 m). On April, 24 a sondage was undertaken at the findspot (ca. 3x3 m. with a depth of ca. 20-50 cm), and 6 more coins were found, including one broken into several pieces. On August 31, 2018, one of the finders found another 5 denarii at the site of the main concentration of coins. It is possible that further searches were also made at this site. The fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown. The identification of the coins was based on the photos that were posted in this video.
The hoard comprised 39 radiates of Gallienus and Salonina, found in the Euripides / Peristeria cave, on the south of the island of Salamis.
14 silver coins: 13 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 20.8-37 g.

summary: 407 silver coins found in two glass bottles. One bottle contained 130 coins, the other 277 pieces: 86 denarii, 321 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Victorinus (AD 269-271). In one of the bottles were also found a pendant medallion (with a denarius of Antoninus Pius) and a silver finger ring.
disposition: Service Régional de l’Archéologie, Ile-de- Franceté; Centre Michel de Boüard – Centre de recherches archéologiques et historiques anciennes et médiévales, Caen

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 7 silver coins seen by T. Gerasimov: 2 denarii, 5 antoniniani: Severus Alexander - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 10.4-17.2 g.

A hoard of 97 tetradrachms (Nero–Severus Alexander), 25 denarii, and 1 antoninianus, found in a trench excavation at Gindaros. As no further excavations were done araound that trench, the archaeological context remains so far uncertain.

At least three aes coins (Domitian and Gallienus), along with numerous other finds, including a tombstone, mortarium, glassware, fibulae, and studs, discovered while digging the foundations of the new gaol (now HMP Usk) on the field known as 'Cae Puta'.
