The two radiates of Gallienus might constitute a hoard, but the addition of the single aes of Domitian throws this into doubt. In lieu of more accurate information concerning their context, it is just as likely that all three are single finds instead of a hoard. Nash-Williams (1928) speculated that the site might have been the location of a fort.
1943 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: 1942 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Antoninus Pius - MAximinus I Thrax (AD 236).

Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 100 denarii, 5 antoniniani: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: 148.6-305.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2226, 105 coins

summary: 775 denarii: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 228).

1918 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian - Victorinus (AD 271); mints: 1006 Rome, 787 Mediolanum, 122 Cologne, 1 Siscia, 1 Viminacium, 1 Antioch: Valerian I and Gallienus - Cludius II/Victorinus (AD 268-271); silver weight: 518.8-2396.6 g.
539 denarii and 538 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-269).
88 silver coins: 7 denarii, 81 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: 45.7-319.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (88 coins)

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. Dr. Harlanov examined 23 pieces: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-219); silver weight: 41.3-66.1 g.
150 coins: 140 sestertii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus/Gallienus (AD 251-268). A silver patera and a lead weight were discovered together with these coins.

The hoard was found in two ceramic vessels hidden under some large stones. It comprised more than 8,500 bronze coins of which 7,978 (Hucher) or 8,117 (Lallemand) radiates and copies were identified. Callu estimated that 5.2% of the coins were imitations. The hoard was found during stone quarrying under some large stones: Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); Silver weight: 1517.4-14518.3
56 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised 497 coins, including 2 denarii and 495 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-260).

Group of 6 coins (silvered antonini) stuck together into 'a column', with a 7th found close by, found in topsoil just outside of apse of bath house in commander's praetorium/principia in Bowes Roman fort, excav. by Hartley & Frere in 1966-67. Latest coin an issue of Constantinus II of AD 332. Coins may have been originally wrapped in linen (in Shotter's coin report). Topsoil above a rubble layer containing pottery, wall plaster, iron nails & building stone, but no other topsoil finds mentioned.D. Shotter, The Roman coins. In Frere, S.S. and Fritts, R.L. 2009. Excavations at Bowes and Lease Rigg Roman Forts, pp.56 to 66. Yorkshire Archaeological Report No. 6, pp. 39.The radiate of Tetricus is given as RIC 100. The coin of Victorinus is listed as a copy. Shotter excludes the nummus from this group.

The assemblage comprised a) a copper-alloy box containing 2 aurei, items of jewellery and a fragment of silk; b) a further earthenware vessel containing a large quantity (10 kilos in total) of small module coins (radiates). 250 of these coins were examined by F. Rever, with the most recent being an issue of Quietus; c) 50 'large bronze' coins were scattered on the surface; d) some iron tools including pruning equipment. It is not clear whether all the constituent parts of the find should be considered to represent a single hoard deposit or at least two separate hoards. Found in a field belonging to M. Denesle (or Denêle) in the course of digging.
Contents of a little purse. Six denarii Septimius Severus - Caracalla.
214 radiates after AD 280. Found in a pit post-dating the rampart in a concreted mass. One official coin and 212 barbarous radiates of small module, one illegible coin.

The hoard comprised an amphora containing approximately 5,400 Roman coins, weighing 143 kilos in total. They were mostly sestertii with some 'middle bronzes' (asses, according to Hollard 1992, 99). Blanchet catalogued a selection of 132 from the collections of the Musée Carnavalet from Gordian III to Postumus Silver: 1, 50 coins; silver weight: 17.4-63.0g.
disposition: Musée Carnavalet, Paris (132 coins); Sanatorium Nestor Pirotte Angicourt (120 coins, possible lost)

summary: The only data published on this hoard indicates that it comprised 800 antoniniani (radiates) dating from the reigns of Gordian III to Gallienus (AD 260-268).
(235) 234 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Hadrian - Philip I; silver weight: 294.1-665.3 g.

The hoard originally comprised 50.591 antoniniani: Gordianus III - Maximian I ( AD 293). Almost the whole hoard was acquired and now 45.873 coins are kept in the Museo di Castelvecchio, Verona. This find is extensively published. 168 kilos.
disposition: Verona, Museo di Castelvecchio, 45873 coins; otherwise dispersed

summary: Unknown number of denarii. 199 entered the museum collection in Silistra: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 217).
200 gold staters of the Bosporan kings found on the banks of the Mortvyy Donets River: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
Unknown number of coins. 4 coins in the museum of Lovech: Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Severus Alexander, Philip II.
Unknown originally number of coins. 18 coins are kept in the Hungarian National Museum in Budapest: Augustus – Gordian III (AD 243-244)
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 700 silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - MArius (AD 269).
More than 1,500 coins were discovered in a bowl. However, only 77 pieces are known in any detail, 5% of the original hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
11 coins discovered in a burial consisting in 1 denarius of Augustus, 5 drachms of Gotarzes II, 1 aureus of Commodus, and 4 aurei of Caracalla.
54 coins found spread close to each other in a layer of ashes: Domitian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown number of coins. 63 antoniniani were seen: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
circa 150 denarii, 30 preserved. Nero-Seveus Alexander (AD 227). 1 nummus of Constantius II is an intruder.
(30) 7 silver and bronze coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoniniani; 1 provincial bronze; 3 bronze unid. denom: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Private collection Andrei Pănoiu - architect, Bucharest, Romania

summary: The hoard, handed to the Serres archaeological service by a local resident, comprised 15 Roman Provincial coins (14 Koinon of Macedonia and 1 Thessalonica). It has been suggested that it is part of the Evelpidis hoard.
4 coins of Gordian III: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii P M S COL VIM (AD 238-244).

The hoard was found inside a vessel, apparently made of iron. The total number of coins found seems to be 90, although some reports detail at least 107. The coins were all bronze issues measuring between 25 and 35mm in diameter: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Monedas conservadas en el Museo Arqueologico, Etnografico e Historico, Vasco, Spain (5 coins)

summary: Part of a larger hoard. 50 silver coins: 13 denarii, 37 antoniniani: Domitian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 64.6-130.2 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3173-3186

summary: 140 silver coins: 26 denarii, 114 antoniniani: Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 175.6-362.9 g.
Unknown number of coins found with a vessel in a wall. The land owner had 9 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan Decius - Postumus.
13 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 216); silver weight: 24.9-37.2g.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 5 pieces are known: Aurelian 2, Tacitus 1, Probus 2; silver weight: 1.0-1.4g.
Group of six coins: aureus of Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I), aureus of Postumus and 4 denarii of Augustus found in grave no. 8.
The hoard comprised an orange paste vessel containing 3 denarii and 214 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Victorinus.
1,606 silver coins: 604 denarii, 1,002 antoniniani of the 1st-3rd centuries AD.
Three aurei of Gallienus (AD 260-268). Two of the coins are soldered. Traces of fire
1,456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 394.1-1819.1g.
37 sestertii: Hadrian - Elagabalus (AD 221-222).
The hoard comprised one or two vessels filled with silver and billon coinage of different sizes of which one was of Gallienus and one Postumus'
(7 kg) (1200+) 22 coins: 1 denarius, 20 antoniniani, 1 bronze: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
6 aurei: Elagabalus - Carinus (AD 283-285).
1,088 denarii and antoniniani were found in a copper vessel: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9221-10309

summary: The hoard was concealed under three stone slabs. There was no evidence of a container.

On the site of the Romano-British settlement at Camerton, near Bath, a small hoard of barbarous radiates, mostly minimi, was found just outside the wall of a small Roman building. It would appear to have been deposited there after the construction of the wall, which was not earlier than mid-third century. With the exception of the piece of larger module, and some scraps of the more usual imitations, the coins of the hoard are radiate minimi of average diameter of 8 mm.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of silver Roman coins, of which 23 were catalogued: 1 denarius, 22 antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: 29.5-57.9g.
The hoard comprised a silver patera on which were placed 23 denarii or antoniniani (radiates)(?) of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
58 antoniniani, ranging from Caracalla to Volusian.
20 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD were find during metal detecting activity. No further information

A hoard of 358 tetradrachms (Septimius Severus - Philip II), denarii (Crispina - Gordian III) and antoniniani (Julia Donna - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in a common-ware jar near the citadel.
2,648 antoniniani (radiates) in a lump of over 5 kg: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (16 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer mentioned these coins in particular: one of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and one of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
1 denarius, 33 antoniniani (radiates), 16 sesterti, 16 antoniniani (radiates) fragments, 4 nummi: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
157 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 43.5-370.6 g.
disposition: Collection Huybrigts, Tongeren, Belgium, in 1902; destroyed by fire in 1914

summary: 1700 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard is thought to have comprised at least 600 coins but only 229 were recovered from the finders. The coins are described as being 'di grande modulo' and this has been interpreted as sestertii: Vespasian/Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found during the construction of a house for Corrado Tedeschi di Modica.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (31 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 5 silver denarii from Septimius Severus to Elagabalus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 9.2g.
2826 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 2824 provincial bronze coins were found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1,065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1,053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.
180 bronze coins: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), Pella (2 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), found in a grave.
ca. 1500 to 2000 coins, but only 528 are identified: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
200-300 denarii of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD found in unknown circumstances. No further information.
676 Roman imperial bronzes found in the ground: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
25 silver coins: 2 republican denarii, 21 imperial denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Total amount of coins is unknown. The hoard contains 1 denarius and 236 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
An unknown number of silver coins: 1 denarius, 16 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2631

summary: Hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 30 coins were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293)
Over 1,001 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Marcus Aurelius - Diocletian (AD 288-289) found stored in a heap at the foot of a stairway leading to the second floor, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 995 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The surviving part of a larger hoard includes 16 denari and 6 antoniniani (radiates) from Mark Antony to Philip I (32 BC-247 AD) kept in a private collection. The original amount of the hoard remains unknown. Given the very little distance between the two findspots, Masi I and Masi II should be two sections of the same hoard deposited in different places by its owner.
43 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 206-210). Found together jewels and dices embedded in a wall.
211 silver coins: 106 denarii, 105 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 242-243).
disposition: Private collection Dr. Coriolan Bucur, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Between 25,000-30,000 coins found in two bronze vessels: 8 or 10 aurei from Hadrian to Severus Alexander; 5 bronze coins (Septimius Severus, Severus Alexander, Philip II, Postumus); 1 bronze medallion of Severus Alexander (with Julia Mamaea); 25,000-30,000 silver and billon coins from Claudius (I/II?) to Postumus; gold weight: c. 64.8 g; Silver: c.25-30,000 coins; Silver weight: c.7427.6-71498.9. Together were found jewelry: 30 gold and silver rings; two or three pairs of gold earrings; a pair of bracelets, two styla, 30 silver spoons; a gold necklace (?).
Uncertain originally number of coins. 66 silver coins: 6 denarii, 60 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 84.9-171.3 g.
1,548 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 204); silver weight: 2,788.4-4,765.7 g.
(300) 229 coins: 1 sestertius, 228 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 64.2-669.9 g.

A small hoard of 45 radiates in a pot dating "to within a few years of AD 280" (Pastscape 343603) found during archaeological excavations of a Roman settlement in the Weedon Road area by Northamptonshire's Archaeological Unit in the 1970s.
6 uncertain imperial coins (Vespasian-Aurelian).
Unknown initial number of coins. 34 antoniniani: Gordian III -Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver weight: 42.5 g+
Around 1,000 antoniniani (radiates) found with an amphora. Among coins, issues of Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian (AD 270-275).
81 coins found in a ceramic vessel whilst demolishing a stable block: 65 antoniniani (radiates), 15 denarii, 1 sestertius: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown original number of coins. 90 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Maximianus I Thrax (AD 235-238)?
2,000 bronze coins, probably, kept in a wooden box: Hadrian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

A farmer from Buprich uncovered an earthenware container filled with many Roman coins in the vicinity of the village. The container appears to have contained more than 1000 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus). 832 of them were described, but giving only the reverse legend, not the type. 727 are listed in FMRD.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 74 denarii (232g) were analysed by the Archaeological Commission: Vespasian Septimius Severus. Four coins were described in detail.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg (1891), Russia; Podillya Antiquities Museum, Kamyanets-Podilsky, Ukraine (4 coins)

summary: A hoard of 94 denarii, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander, found at the Roman fort Vetoniana, inside the enclosure wall of the temple Jupiter Dolichenus. The hoard included objects as well.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 63 antoniniani (radiates ) are known: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
203 silver coins, 5 denarii, 198 antoniniani (radiates), found in earthenware with two golden jewels: Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).
140 provincial bronze coins, possible kept in a leather bag. 110 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249)
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 00518/1-110

summary: 745 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 293).
61 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found together with a bronze brooch.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M IV 8346-8406

summary: 50 silver coins, 10 seen: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CLXIV in 1957

summary: The hoard comprised 180 Provincial bronzes from Nicopolis, found next to a small countryside road, at Phloriada-Valtos, Plakanida, at the border of Aetolia and Acarnania. The list given here follows Calomino.
A hoard of three provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.
6 antoniniani (radiates) found in a small ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 2 Probus 2.
43,433 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 274-275); silver weight: 11726.9-54290.3 g
79 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210). "Only 18 coins were found at first, the remainder being recovered when an excavation of the site was carried out the following month."

The hoard was found in a funerary casket with an ornate lid decorated with a red marble plaque. The casket contained cremated bone, two small amphorae, a glass vessel, a copper-alloy spatula and 7 dupondii and asses from Tiberius to Severus Alexander.
The hoard comprised 25 sestertii from Hadrian to Valerian I (AD 253-260).
A hoard of three large gold medallions, 23 aurei, 4 gold bars, 2 gold tintinnabula and several amulets of gold and lapis lazuli, probably deposited in the reign of Gordian III or Philip the Arab.
disposition: BNF, Paris (Alexander Medaillions); G. de Demetrio (Gold Objects)

summary: A series bronze coins (Vespasian - Maximinus Thrax), found by farm workers close to Landwehr; a further three coins are reported to have been found close to Landwehr or at the Nordostseekanal. Not belonging to the find is a cast provincial coins of Samos (Trajan Decius).

HER record of a scattered hoard of 117 coins from Gallienus to Tetricus "with one very clipped denarius" and further finds from area. As far as it is possible to ascertain, this is not part of the other hoards recorded from the parish.
Five denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Septimius Severus, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
An unpublished hoard of 3 provincial coins (Dium, Thessalonica and the Koinon of Macedonia) and 4 blanks, from a building within the city.
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous, 1 Commodus, 1 Alexander Severus), found in a grave in the west cemetery of Thessalonica (area of Ramona).

The hoard comprised a cylindrical copper-alloy vessel containing 450 bronze coins, of which the majority were sestertii. Not all the coins were identified but those that were dated from the reign of Domitian to that of Severus Alexander.
1,839 coins: 1,834 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 5 Ptolemaic bronze coins: Ptolemaic dynasty - Aurelian (AD 270-275). "Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly'.
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: The hoard was recovered from the site of a Gallo-Roman vicus during illegal excavations and comprised a denarius of Septimius Severus and 561 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus (ad 193-211).
7 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
357 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 97.4-445.3 g.
disposition: Collezioni Governative del Medagliere Milanese, Italy (in 1923).

summary: The hoard comprised one denarius and 72 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Aurelian (AD 270-275) found with a bronze vessel.
160 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: AM Zagreb (41); ZM Sarajevo (114); Fojnica monastery; dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing between 1,300 and 1,500 copper-alloy coins from Antoninus Pius to Tetricus I.

A hoard of 387 silver coins, including a large quantity of posthumous Philip Philadelphus (121, year 19 to 32, i.e. 31-18 BC), Roman denarii (141, up to AD 207), Syrian tetradrachms (29), Arabian didrachms (Trajan, 3 coins), as well as Parthian drachms (92 up to Artabanus IV, 213-227). The later coins of Severus and the members of his family are in mint state. Found in the Nineveh excavations in the 1929-30 season.
disposition: British Museum (154 coins); the Birmingham City Art Gallery (17 coins); Sir Charles Hyde (25 coins); Bagdad museum (196)

summary: 134 sestertii: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

At the beginning of 1884, a mass grave dating to the 1793 war was found south of the Hammermühle in Wiesbaden-Biebrich. At the same place was also found a hoard of ca. 30 Roman denarii, ranging from the Republic to Elagabalus. FMRD lists 32 coins. The composition of the hoard is highly unusual and FMRD considers the last 3 coins (Antoninus Pius and Elagabalus) as potential intruders. If that was the case, the hoard would end with Titus.
4 antoniniani (Gordian III - Trajan Decius) found during field work.
103 coins, range: Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus. No further details.

The hoard was characterised as a 'cachette'. It comprised approximately 350 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Aurelian and other emperors of the period. The coins were generally well-preserved.
6 silver coins: 3 denarii, 3 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247) found during excavations
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45361-45365, 52259

summary: 23 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 10 denarii, 11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2678, 23 coins

summary: IARCH record for a small hoard of 10 radiates. Possibly associated with the Chalgrove II hoard (IARCH-CB9058) but recorded separately due to uncertainty over this association.
90 silver coins: 36 denarii, 54 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius - Valerian I (AD 257); silver weight: 114.7-196.4 g.
28 coins found in the Dionysos House: 1 sestertius, 22 provincial coins, 5 undocumented coins: Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Julia Domna) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised a whiteware ceramic jug contained approximately 2,000 coins of Postumus.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 156 silver coins: 147 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 247); silver weight: 198.8-366.5 g.

56 bronzes of Postumus. Only 26 were considered worth preserving. The coins were acquired by the musée de Douai under inventory no. 6271. The dating in AD 270-271 is based on the abbreviation PIAV (vonius), nomen of Victorinus, on one of the coins.
2 aurei of Carausius, found in spoil after the construction of a building near Ashbourne.
205 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

Originally were 500 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 120 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Clodius Albinus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Until AD 253, Mints represented: Rome, except 2 from Laodicea for Septimius Severus and Geta; 2 from Antioch for Elagabalus and Philip I; 2 from Viminiacum for Treboninanus Gallus and 2 from Milan for 'les divi'; after AD 253: 1 Rome, 9 Cologne, 1 Viminiacum, 1 Milan, 1 2nd eastern Mint and 1 uncertain. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 698.4-1425.8g
116 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). The issues are from the mints from Moesia and Thracia, mainly Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum and Viminacium
170 provincial coins: Nicopolis ad Istrum 77, Marcianopolis 69, Hadrianopolis 6, Odessos 4, Anchialus 9, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 antoniniani are kept in the local museum of Sevlievo: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
450 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic urn: Philip I - Valerian I and Galienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), of which only 39 pieces were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Few hundred coins. Only 98 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) are recovered: Elagabalus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).
94 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 20 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 825-844 (20 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 27 coins from Gallienus to Postumus and Tetricus I and one gold ring. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 8.7 and 31.5 g.

The hoard comprised 11 sestertii from Domitian to Balbinus. The coins in the hoard were stacked on top of each other and corroded together, forming a cylindrical shape. It appears they were originally in a small bag or pouch which has not been preserved.

The hoard comprised 9,000 antoniniani (radiates) (35kg) found in a terracotta vessel: Valerian I - Dioletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293). L. Dancoisne bought 1000 of the more interesting and better conserved coins, which may not be representative of the whole assemblage. Found whilst digging in garden; silver weight: 1621.1-11249.1 g+.
88 silver coins: 1 denarius, 87 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Quintillus (AD 270).

7 antoniniani (radiates), all of Postumus from a single collection. The coins could be part of a hoard, or form a hoard in themselves. No information regarding the circumstances of their discovery are known.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 150 sestertii and dupondii, asses or antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Probus (AD 276-282).
Around 50 antoniniani were discovered. Coins were issued by Gordian III, Philip I, Philip I for Otacilia Severa, and Valerian I (AD 253-259).

Unknown initial number of coins. 15 bronze and billon coins entered the collection of the museum in Cagliari: 7 sestertii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 4.6-19.5g.

IARCH record for a scattered hoard of 6 denarii. Other coins have been recorded from the immediate area but they were not considered to be part of this hoard. For full details and images see SOM-D0A907.

The hoard comprised 104 small bronzes [antoniniani (radiates)]of Tetricus I. Of 97 examined by Bizeul, 76 were illegible and 27 difficult to recognise because their legends were incomplete, their reverses were barbarous or their flans were too small to strike. It is clear these coins were all barbarous radiates.

On road construction activity a hoard of 300-500 denarii was discovered. Coins of Vespasian, Domitianus, Traianus, Hadrianus, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Septimius Severus and Severus Alexander were noticed.
26 antoniniani found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma' with a small ceramic vessel: Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).

There is debate about whether 2-3000 coins were found (Lebarbier-Arnoux) or 5-6000 coins (Bottin). The librarian in Valenciennes, Hécart, saw about 500. An English officer, Drummond Hay, took a large portion of the hoard. Found with a ceramic vessel Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).

A hoard of 162 provincial coins, 27 of which were illegible. The remaining ones were: 134 coins from Sinope (Antoninus Pius - Valerian & Gallienus) and 1 from Trapezus (Gordian III). The hoard was found in a burnt and shattered container in the remains of a Roman villa, on the northern side of the Sinope peninsula.
1499 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised 381 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus and was found under a complete Roman tile. The coins were acquired by the City Library of Bourg.
(c. 150) 118 silver coins: 108 denarii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: c.188.8-387.2 g.

In 1927 about 360 denarii and antoniniani (Caracalla - Postumus) were unearthed. The coins were strewn on the ground, on a place located on the floodplain of the river Rhine. There was also half of a longsword, remnants of scissors, 4 bronze rings and 50 tokens of glass and glass base.

The hoard was found whilst dredging the marshland close to the railroad from Saint-Omer to Calais. Silver: 1636 (1450) antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver weight: 442.7-2044.0 g.
Unknown initial number of coins. 2788 antoniniani: Philip I - Gallienus (AD 260-268)
disposition: National Museum, Belgrade, Serbia (2,639 coins); inv.no. 233-697, 730, 731; National Museum, Niš (149 coins), inv.no. 1668-1786

summary: 339 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Silver: 254, 85 coins; silver weight: 69.6-316.5g.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 600 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius. A further sestertius of Marcus Aurelius was overstruck with a double sestertius of Postumus. The coins were arranged in textile bags. Fragments of the bags survived where coins touched the walls of the vessel.
79 denarii found en ruleau while digging a ditch: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 223). Some coins may be intruders.
disposition: Collection of the public grammar school in Kalmar

summary: Hoard of radiates from the excavations at Angel Yard, Colchester. The exact number is uncertain - the existence of a scattered hoard was assumed from the profile of coin loss at the site. The coins were distributed in an accumulation of topsoil dating from the third century to the medieval period. A group of 9 denarii to AD 222, a group of silvered radiates and a group of barbarous radiates are all thought to have come from this hoard accoding to Crummy and Crummy (1990, 4) but it is perhaps more likely that more than one hoard was present within this group.
The hoard comprised a wine amphora containing 953 coins, including 937 sestertii, 6 dupondii and 10 asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
Circa 20,000 antoniniani (radiates). Among the issuers were Trajan Decius and Tetricus I.
1,204 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1,199 sestertii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 268).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 22 coins entered museum collection in Plovdiv: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2168

summary: HER record of a hoard of 102 coins found in the river at Thornborough. Appears to be a hoard dislodged from the river bank rather than an accumulation of finds deposited in the river. Latest coin Carausius or Diocletian.
Hoard of circa 100 coins. Only two pieces are known: Claudius I sestertius, Caracalla provincial bronze minted in Serdica.
24 large bronze cooins (sestertii and double sestertii?): Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 460 silver coins. Auvray mentions Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius, Volusian, Trebonianus Gallus and Valerian. In 1834, Pesche compiled a more complete catalogue. His source (although he does not acknowledge it) appears to be a manuscript held by the Sociétè d'Agriculture which describes Roman coins found in the city of Le Mans and its environs. Pesche adds to his catalogue coins of Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Lucilla and Pupienus. It is not clear whether these coins are part of the hoard. Silver: c.460 (1, 173) coins; silver weight: c. 576.7-1295.1g.
344 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 202); silver weight: 629.0-1075.4g
Circa 100 silver coins. Y. Youroukova have seen 30: 10 denarii, 20 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

In 1837, 143 denarii and antoniniani were found on a field (Mühlen) next to the lime kiln, during excavation of an old boundary stone. No trace of a container was seen. Of these 143 coins, only 32 (Tiberius - Severus Alexander) have been described.
7 denarii undescribed (Vespasian - Severus Alexander) found in fortifications.
7 coins: 4 denarii, 2 sestertii, 1 bronze found a in a layer of fire: Antoninus Pius - Severus alexander (AD 222-228).
The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 72 Provincial bronzes, 70 of Gallienus from Lacedaemon, 1 of Septimius Severus from Gytheion and 1 of Caracalla from Mantineia.
15 probably antoniniani (radiates). According to NUMIS they are dated around AD 270. No further information.
6 tetradrachms of Alexandria found in a grave ranging from Probus to Constantine I.
Found in a ceramic vessel, 120 coins: 66 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 147.7-320.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2442, 120 coins

summary: 332 silver coins: 45 denarii, 287 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 383-758.6 g. Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum, vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M II 3011-3330 (320 coins)

summary: 27 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 35.6-71.4 g.

During excavation of a ditch in front of the Spickelstraße house 3 a hoard of denarii, ranging from Nero to Alexander Severus, was unearthed in 1958, from which 640 specimens were salvaged and could have been transferred to the Kempten Heimatmuseum. It is not sure that all coins are preserved. 2 antoniniani are also listed.
39 silver coins: 1 denarius, 38 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (39 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 12 coins from Volusian to Salonina, found together in a single mass.

The coins were found in a stone sarcophagus along with some ashes. They comprised coins dating from the reign of Augustus (Altar of Lyon) to the reign of Maximinus (of Thrace?). The coins were found during the demolition of a tumulus.
Scarce Information on a hoard, in which circa 20 antoniniani depict portarits of seven emeperors between AD 238-268 from Gordian III to Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Museum of Sain-Sulpice, France, but no records of them in the registers.

summary: The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Unknown initial number of silver coins. 6 coins are known in the collection of the Salzburger Museum Carolino Augusteum: Septimius Severus 2, Julia Domna 1, Caracalla 1, Maximinus I Thrax 1, Gordian III 1.
The Musée de Rouen has preserved 25 coins from this find, initially, it consisted of 33 antoniniani (radiates).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (collection Thaurin), France

summary: c.50 loose coins and concreted mass weighing 1.8kg· The hoard probably consists of c. 400 ish coins which have corroded into a single concreted mass - the single block weighs approximately 2 kilos and there are another c. 50 loose coins.An organic container was thought likely - traces of leather were found.
The hoard comprised coins from Gallienus to Probus. There are some doubts on the real number of coins from this hoard!
The hoard comprised '57 Roman coins including 1 of Antonina (sic), 1 of Antoninus Pius or Commodus and 1 of Maximinus.'
35 antoniniani (radiates), 28 seen: Marius - Tetricus (AD 271-274); silver weight: c.10.5 g.

Coins run from Mark Antony to Trajan Decius, although it has been argued that the last coins could be intrusive. In that case, the hoard would end with issues of Gordian III. 81,096 (and not 81,044!) coins were published in 1934 by Mouchmov, after a further 20,000+ coins had been dispersed. The total number of coins therefore exceeds 101,096 specimens. The difference between our comput and the 81,044 coins mentioned in the original publication resides in an error in counting the number of coins of Commodus (3146, whereas 3191 is correct) and reporting the correct number of coins of Caracalla in the table p. 6 of Mouchmov's publication. Note that further errors have occurred for Trajan (p. 21, last three entries, where numbers do not add up).
disposition: National Museum, Sofia (ca. 68,783 coins). Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria: inv.nos. 2807-2829, 4301-16363 (12,261 coins: Nero - Gordian III)

summary: 67 coins found in the ruins of an ancient building, on "Trajan's road": 66 silver, 1 bronze of Philip II of Macedon: Philip II of Macedon - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A hoard of 21 badly corroded provincial bronze coins, dating from Septimius Severus to Gordian III, found in Dura Europos.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1,500 and 2,000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver weight: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: The hoard comprised 12 Roman coins, of which 8 were identified by H. Desaye: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 7.5 g.

33 Alexandrian tetradrachms and a fragment of a bronze-ring. Found in a wooden jar in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293).
Hoard of initial of just over 100 aurei, 91 recovered (650 g = two Roman pounds): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 231).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Madrid (at the moment); Provincial Archaeological Museum of Cáceres, Spain (final destination)

summary: (Circa 86) 14 aurei: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282)? Found together with 2 gold bracelets, 2 gold earrings, 1 Gold chain.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (10 aurei)

summary: (1000-1200) 113 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tetrarchy (AD 293-294); silver weight: 217.1-1,499.1 g.
596 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); Silver weight: 745.6-1548.5 g.
disposition: Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9091-9632; 9469-9588 (557 coins)

summary: 56 denarii: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 214); silver weight: 87.8-167.0g.
disposition: Voralberg Museum, Bregenz, (initial 51 coins, in 1977 46); Private collection, Innsbruck (1 coin), Austria

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing 550 3rd century ADcoins including issues of Gordian III and Philip I.
c. 50 antoniniani (radiates) of which is known 1 Tetricus I imitation.
2211 silver coins: 10 denarii, 2201 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Diva FaustinaI) - Valerian I (AD 259); silver weight: 2765.1-5725.2g
5 antoniniani (radiates) of Probus and 'few hundred smaller bronze coins from the time of the thirty tyrants' (AD 260-274).
108 denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
An urn of antoniniani (radiates) found between Sizzano and Fara. Only two coins are known of Philip I and Claudius II, as being donated to the museum in Fara.
disposition: Museo dal Sig. Luigi Spagnolini di Fara (on the May 10, 1886; donation record no. 723 (3)

summary: (c. 3000) 1831 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 811.0-3749.0 g.
Originally 164 coins, only 45 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 299).
25 silver coins, 5 recovered: Septimius Severus Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 7.1-9.3 g.

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 334 coins were extracted from a hole sunk in the earth below two large stones, placed as it seemed, purposely above it. The coins were of Gallienus, Probus, Tacitus, and Claudius Gothicus.

Hoard of 14 kilos of antoniniani (radiates) found during the construction of the overpass on the Corso Ivrea. 601 coins were transferred from the Regional Museum of Torino to the Soprintendenza della Valle d'Aosta: Trebonianus Gallus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
1867 coins: 1650 antoniniani (radiates), 215 imitation antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius, 1 bronze: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 504.5-2330.3 g.
A hoard of 428 denarii dating from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (235/236) and one Caesarean drachm of Septimius Severus found at Sulakyurt.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkez

summary: 31 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 272-273) found in a pottery jar during excavations beneath the floor in room of a house.
The hoard comprised 132 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
Hoard given to Sfax Museum in October 1961, examined by Salama: 36 antoniniani: Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole)? (AD 260-268).
14 silver coins, 13 known: 12 antoniniani (radiates) 1 denarius: Septimius Severus - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 4.2-33.3 g.
14 denarii (late Republic to Severus Alexander) were found in 1906 in front of the door sill of cellar 83 (in the Roman settlement).

Small hoard of 15 ant. of Gallienus to Tetricus II, from 'Dover General Deposits', reported on by Peter Curnow & Richard Reece, all show evidence of wear, majority clipped.Reece, R. 2012. The Roman coins. In B. Philp The Discovery and Excavation of the Roman Shore-fort at Dover, Kent. Kent Archaeological Monographs 11. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 108.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing one silver coin and an unknown number of copper-alloy coins of Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Julia Mamaea.

In 1897 a hoard of silver coins was discovered a little south of the Ladenburg/Keplerstraße junction. Only half of the coins are known, because the others were sold to America. The list given here includes a Greek coin, and 129 denarii and antoninini (late Republic to Postumus).
The hoard comprised 1 denarii and 25 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Victorinus. The coins were stuck together with corrosion products.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 400 Roman sestertii from Nerva or Trajan to Postumus. 77 coins were examined.
This hoard of twenty three coins was found in 1928, and it consists mostly of cast imitations of the second-century aurei. Many of them are mould-linked.
Circa 2,000 denarii but only 20 pieces indicate emperors from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax.
The hoard comprised 38 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Gallienus (sole reign).
(150) 102 bronze coins: 1 imperial, 149 provincial coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 866 (102 coins)

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani. 27 coins entered museum collection in Haskovo: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. N 656, N 1039

summary: 67 silver coins: 21 antoniniani (radiates), 46 denarii: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: A hoard of 653 denarii (Mark Antony – Geta) and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Trajan), found in a garden at Muswell Hill in 1928, together with a silver spoon and a bronze ring, and pieces of the earthenware pot which had contained them.

In 1873 a hoard was found during peat digging in the Burgau moss. It comprised 7 bronze jars, 3 golden rings, and 40 coins, ranging from Elagabalus to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins except one were antoniniani. This was probably not the entirety of the hoard.
The hoard comprised a tinned copper-alloy vessel containing several hundred antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 438 (or only 380) sestertii found in a black coarse ceramic vessel: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
96 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).

This find can only be traced on paper, as it is only available as a manuscript by Christian Friedrich Hoffmann. It is stated that Hoffmann led excavations in the fort in the years 1791, 1800, 1804 and 1813-1815. His extensive manuscript was found in the Princely Wied archive in Neuwied in 1811. In 1991 the content was revised in Frankfurt am Main. Hoffmann describes 256 coins that are said to have been found “in a yellow metal chalice”. Thanks to Hoffmann's detailed description, almost all coins could be assigned. These are 213 denarii and 43 antoniniani (radiate). Most date from the reigns of Septimius Severus, Elagabalus, and Severus Alexander. The final coin, minted in AD 259.
The hoard comprises 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I with a tpq of AD 274.
Unknown initial number of coins. 82 bronze coins were studied: 81 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Titus - Gordian III (AD 240/241).

The hoard comprised 214 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Gordian III which are today lost. Also found in the excavations as isolated finds were a denarius of Septimius Severus, and 2 bronzes of Severus Alexander. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 313.3-487.1g
166 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 208.9-430.2 g.
disposition: Village museum, Slăveni, Romania, 122 coins; Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova, Romania, 44 coins

summary: The hoard comprised a broken vessel containing more than 850 radiates (the total is estimated at approximately 1,000 coins). The hoard was buried in a cemetery, not far from the village. The hoard was discovered by chance.
In the vicus was found a hoard of 161 sestertii: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 267).

14 aureii (13 mounted): Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 204); gold weight 110 g. Found with a bronze pitcher. The content: two crosses; three chains; a brooch; sixty-eight pendants and sixty-four grains of necklace; fourteen coins of Roman emperors of the second-third century, the Antonines mainly, and two bracteates.
18 antoniniani (raddiates) found in the dump of the ancient quarry: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
About 100 antoniniani up to the 3rd century AD.
(+38) 38 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 7.9-46.6 g.
The hoard comprised 225 sestertii from Trajan to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 2 silver bracelets, 2 gold finger rings and 197 radiates from Gordian III, Philip, Philip II, Otacillia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Saloninus.
The hoard comprised approximately 50 silver coins (almost certainly radiates) from Gordian III to Gallienus.

The hoard comprised two ceramic urns that contained more than 100kg of Roman coins (according to Payan-Dumoulin) or 40kg (according to Vallentin) equating to approximately 12,000 coins. Only 4,685 coins, all radiates, were catalogued: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 3241.0-14999.1 g.

The hoard comprised approximately 400 coins (although Ledru states the total was more than 1400 coins - an error?). Hucher compiled an inventory of 260 sestertii which were bought by the Musée du Mans Found in a field on the Villeneuve farm. Hollard gives a total number of 280 coins: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique du Mans, France (1892) - 260 coins

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 31 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M VI 9663-9693 (31 coins)

summary: A hoard of 15 coins, found in a grave (grave 4) during the excavations at Pylos, in Volimidia, north of Chora. It has been described as 13 sestertii and 2 antoniniani, though Vlachogianni and Tourastoglou give a slightly different account of the emperors represented (see under References).
Unknown number of silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel. N. Moushmov examined 119 pieces: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
1,439 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) found as a heap in an underground room during excavations of a house.

The hoard was discovered in 1933 by a farmer 100 m north of Rembrechts. 88 coins (mostly denarii, with some bronze coins, ranging from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander) were associated with jewellery. Most of the objects found with the coins were of silver.

The hoard comprised a large earthenware vessel containing 1,100 bronze coins (for the most part sestertii) and 30 'small coins with surface silvering' (radiates). A summary catalogue of 200 of the best preserved examples was made by F. Homo. The hoard was found by workmen from the Letellier company during quarrying for stone. It was found at only a slight depth 'faible profondeur'.
2 antoniniani (radiates) of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Circa 2,000 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
1 as, 1 sestertius, 1 denarius and 7555 radiates and a bronze ring to AD 274.
5 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Valerianus I (AD 253-260).
30 antoninianii, ranging from Gordian III to Volusian, were unearthed at the Roman fort Biriciana, on the via principalis near the porta dextra during excavations in 1892.
Six sestertii: Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander 2, Julia Mammea, Maximinus I Thrax, Paulin (Diva) brought together with other Roman materials: glass urns, bricks.

The hoard was found in 1906 after a farmer discovered some coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus and Claudius II at the same findspot where two years previously 100 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus and Tetricus I and II had been found. As a result, Vigneron-Jousselandière excavated the findspot, discovering 7 silver ligula and a ceramic vessel containing approximately 3,500 antoniniani (radiates). At the middle of the vessel was a radiate of Philip I, 39 worn denarii, 1 aureus of Postumus and a gold finger ring. The ligulae or spoons, the finger ring, the denarii, the aureus of Postumus and 450 radiates were acquired by the Musée départemental d'archéologie. Vigneron-Jousselandière possessed 2,651 radiates (in 1907).
376 silver coins from Elagabalus to Gordian III (AD 238-244). Found in a cooking pot together with silver brooches, bracelets, fingerings, chain.
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania; mixed with the rest of museum collection; National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest; jewelry.

summary: Three accounts of the discovery exist, but all give different details and there is no other contemporary authority which could be used. Both brass coins (possibly including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina) and minimi were found in 1869 and have been assumed to be part of one and the same hoard. The three accounts of the range of the first brass gave either Severus Alexander, Gallienus or Maximian as the last emperor represented, and it is now impossible to be certain which account is correct. In 1935, C.H.V. Sutherland examined 105 radiate minims from this hoard. These proved to be exactly similar to the 317 radiate minims which were acquired by Sir Arthur Evans at Bristol some years before, along with 6 regular antoniniani (NC, 1934, 92-103) [no. 804]. Dr. Sutherland therefore concluded that these 317 and 105 radiate minims all came from the Whitchurch hoard. The 6 regular antoniniani may or may not have come from the same find. They were of Victorinus (3) and Tetricus II (3). With the 317 minims, were a rough lump of copper and a piece of sheet metal. The 422 minims copied the following prototypes: Gallic Empire types (249), types of Claudius II (23), miscellaneous types (150). The large brass may have been collected together, to be melted down to make into radiate minims.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 1,440 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Of this total, 1,424 were catalogued by Chanel. Silver: 1358 coins; Silver weight: 246.9-3528.5g
41 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 41 imitations in an alloy of copper and lead: 1 Valerian I, 40 Gallienus (AD 257-258).

140 antoniniani were found on the bottom of a ceramic vessel by the excavation team of the University of Milan. Based on preliminary information drawn from the web, coins in this hoard date to the reign of Gallienus (AD 260-268).

Found during excavations in the Roman villa rustica of Hüttwilen-Stutheien, in the north-western corner of room VIII. A group of 5 coins, 2 sestertii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 3 antoniniani (Gordian III). Possibly a purse.
The hoard comprised 1,548 antoniniani (radiates) and 2 denarii, from Caracalla to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 1,938.2 g. and 4,027.1 g.
220 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of small radiates (officials or imitations?), from Victorinus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 91 denarii and 416 sestertii from Nero to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique départemental de Guiry-en-Vexin, France

summary: 108 kg found in a large ceramic jar and, probably, a box or, rather, of a canvas bag or leather, according to the rectangular shape of the second heap of coins: 41,200 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius. Among issuers Valerian I, Gallienus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Claudius II, Postumus, Laelianus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II. Notably Gallienus and Claudius II (27%), the Gallo-Roman emperors Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II in particular (56%), and local imitations. A rare denarius of Tetricus I.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel holding approximately 300 'small bronzes' (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 263).
"Few hundreds", only 89 were seen: Balbinus - Maximian I (AD 294).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80313, 54 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 50 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 253-270.

The hoard was found in the ruins of a small round temple and comprised a tripod cauldron containing 251 Roman sestertii from Domitian to Gordian III. Coins of Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus were the most numerous.
Unknown number of denarii. 56 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Nero - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2590

summary: 76 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 18.9-30.0g.
444 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Together were found two silver spoons
The hoard comprised a large cup containing 635 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 332 were identified. Silver weight: 172.4-792.8g.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 122 silver denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
unknown initial number of coins. 154 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2447-2561 (154 coins) - stolen

summary: The hoard comprised two separate deposits. The first contained 28 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Postumus. The second contained 622 radiates from Philip I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270. The circumstances of discovery means that a clear relationship between the two hoards cannot be established with any certainty.
6,442 silver coins: 6,395 denarii, 47 antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); weight of 21 kg.

A hoard of 4 denarii (including a plated one) and 27 bronze coins (5 Hellenistic, 1 Rhoemetalces and 21 provincial coins), found in grave T4 in Lithochori. Only the latest of the provincial coins are identified.
+100 coins dating from Philip I to Valerian and Gallienus. No catalogue was made and no further information given about the composition of the hoard.
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.
27 denarii: Vespasian for Titus (Caesar) - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: scattered in post pole - interpreted as save hoard, not ritual construction votive

summary: 12 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I and ending ca. AD 255, found on the Zugerberg.
disposition: Amt für Denkmalpflege und Archäologie, Zug

summary: A hoard of 8 Roman Provincial coins from the mints of Thessalonica, Edessa, Pella and the Macedonian Koinon from the period AD 222-235, found in grave 52 in the western cemetery of Pella.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Popovo and Targovishte: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Popovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 306 (92 coins); History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 689 (13 coins)

summary: Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).
151 antoniniani: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Local museum Govora, Vâlcea County, Romania (1966); Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania (101 coins spread through the coin collection)

summary: The hoard was found in a large ceramic vessel. Within the vessel were five corroded blocks of coins, each coated with very hard clay. Two thirds of the hoard was cleaned (except for 2 blocks weighing 5.5kg) and it appears that there were approximately 1,500 coins (bronzes and radiates). Between 200 and 250 coins were of the emperors between Augustus and Gallienus. The others were of Aurelian, Probus and Diocletian. The hoard was found by a farm labourer.
4 bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235). Found together with an iron scale, a bronze weigh and scale pan fragments. Most likely ot a set for weighing.
Uknown number of silver Roman coins. 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 2 coins of Gordian III are known.

The coins were found amongst fragments of ceramic building material (brick). As coins were very rare finds on this site, it is likely that they represent a small purse hoard or a portion of a larger deposit. 7 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 4.2-15.9g.
1,100 antoniniani discovered in unknown circumstances. No further Information.
Silver: 1000+ (83) antoniniani/radiates: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 271.0-1249.0 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (978 coins); dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 radiates of 'the epoque of Postumus and some contemporary official and ursurper emperors.'

A hoard comprising 5 sestertii from Domitian to Macrinus. It has been interpreted as a purse or a small votive deposit. It was found on a hilltop above a cliff during metal detectorist's surveys (2002 and 2004).
(1430) 976 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228). Found together with silverware and jewelry.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (976 coins)

summary: An uncertain number of coins. Only two denarii of Caracalla were identified.
Unknown initial number of coins. 815 silver coins found with a metal bucket: Julia Domna to Philip I; silver weight: 1019.3-2117.9g
disposition: National History of Antiquities Bucharest, Romania (815 coins) - 1886

summary: The three coins found are likely to represent a portion of a larger hoard. The denarius of Balbinus was given to Desjobert; the second was given to the Mans Museum and the third to M. Nepveu of Bellefille.
disposition: Musée de Mans., France; Mr. Nepveu of Bellefille.

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1,400 radiates from Gallienus to Tacitus Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 337g and 1084g.
Circa 150 antoniniani (radiates). 77 coins, including 24 copies. Together was found a small bronze hatchet: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c.35.0-156.5g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (collection Thaurin), France (77 coins). Hoards file in the Archives of the Museum (no inv.nos)

summary: 1,587 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

7,000 coins were found in a pot, consisting of only three types (2 of Tetricus, 1 of Claudius II Gothicus). At the time, they believed that they were set aside to serve as Charon's obol for fallen soldiers.
Over 747 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 262-263) found in a pile on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 744 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: Of those seen (934), were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Sverus to Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 1364.0-1708.8g.

The hoard comprised a greyware ceramic vessel containing 6,000 coins from Valerian I to Probus. The last coin is of Probus, Lyon mint, AD 281 (Bastien type 347 or 348). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 1161.2g and 6865.6g.

The hoard comprised 15 denarii and radiates from Nerva to Valerian and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257 to 258. The exact findspot of the hoard is not known, beyond the fact that it was found on the site of Colonia Ulpia Traiana. This ensemble could have been part of a larger hoard. The date of the find is described as several decades before 2010, when the hoard was published by Reuter.

(c. 180) 31 antoniniani (radiates). Although are mention imperial portraits from Pupienus to Gallienus and Salonina the only more accurate Information on 31 coins is for issuers from Gordian III to Valerian I. The tpq hypothetically can be placed on AD 268; silver weight: 225.0 g.
disposition: Musée Château d'Annec, France (partially); Inv.no. 5352; registre d'entrées, I, p. 184, no. 5352

summary: A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: 8 provincial bronze coins issued under Gordian III by Edessa (6 coins) and either Edessa or Carrhae (2 coins).

Found during excavations, in the Mithraeum, sector NW, niveau de fréquentation (found in 1994, 69 coins) and above in the demolition layer (found in 1993, 4 coins). Hoard, most probably packed in a container of perishable material, no traces found; 73 aes coins, Nero (?) to Philip I, mostly sestertii with a few dupondii and asses.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: 128 silver coins (antoniniani?): Balbinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

Hoard of 651 coins found in several ceramic vessels and a textile cloth. 570 coins were studied: 16 denarii, 96 antoniniani (radiates), 458 bronzes: Galba - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: 134.0-1792.9g. One of the Postumus double sestertius is overstruck on a Marcus Aurelius sestertius of the type VICTORIAE AVG S C.
21 antoniniani: Valerian I - Gallienus (AD 2659-268). Found in a ceramic jug with one handle.
disposition: National Bank of Romania, Numismatic Collection, Bucharest

summary: A hoard of Roman bronze coins, next to a few gold ones, found during the construction of the railrepair workshop in Neustadt. It was acquired by the museum in three successive lots (A-C: 26 coins, 5 coins, 1 coin).

Before 1939, an archaeologist bought a hoard comprising 2,065 antoniniani (radiates) from a clerk in Évron. The hoard appears to have come from the north of the département, perhaps Aron or Évron, or, according to Cordonnier is another hoard from Jublains: Trajan Decius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
101 coins: 16 denarii, 85 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight 122.1-240.8 g.
disposition: Regional Historical Museum, Vidin, Bulgaria; inv.no. 591

summary: The Wiggensbach hoard was discovered in 1889 in Waldegg. The hoard consists of jewellery, the quantity and typology of which is not described by FMRD, and silver coins, mostly denarii and at least 4 antoniniani, with coins ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander. 384 of them were bought by the Heimatmuseum in Kempten. 25 remained in a private collection. A list of them exists, but it gives only the name of the emperor. FMRD speaks of 407 denarii, but lists only 401 coins among which a few antoniniani.
disposition: Allgäuer Heimatmuseum, Kempten, 25 specimens in private collections.

summary: A small hoard of 30 coins, ranging from Gallienus to Diocletian, discovered on the site of a Romano-British villa, on a rough stone pathway next to a building. The building had been in use from the middle of the third century, and was demolished soon after 367.
Unknown initial number of coins. 81 antoniniani (radiates) are available: Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 18.5-80.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. XVII, XXXIV; History Museum, Sliven, Bulgaria (3 coins); History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1066 /0-12/

summary: In 1966 evidence of another coin hoard from Eining was made public. The coins were found between 1958 and 1965. The hoard included at least 20 denarii, ranging from Trajan to Maximinus. It is probably not complete.
IARCH record for a group of 4 silver radiates found fused together. For further details and images see NMS-865B3E. Two of the coins could not be identified due to their condition.
167 silver coins: 39 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLI

summary: A hoard of at least 202 radiates. The latest coin in the hoard is radiate of Gallienus (sole reign) from Milan mint dating to AD 262. Mint data exists for this hoard but TAF is not specific enough to allocate mints to rulers. Museum Inventory No: 75-7. Silver: 8, 223 coins; Silver weight: 71.8-592.1
508 silver coins: 19 denarii, 489 denarii: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
(+100) 122 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251); silver weight: 34.5-314.1g.
Unknown number of antoniani were found in unknown circumstances. 6 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Trebonianus Gallus 1, Valerian I 2, Gallienus 2, Claudius ?? 1.
This hoard is recorded at the level of the coin: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver weight: 243.1-1909.4g.
4811 denarii and antoniniani, found in one (or two?) urns, in the garden of the school. Coins range from Caracalla to Postumus.
The hoard comprised 100 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I, Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
26 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 254). With silver jewelry.
The hoard was found in 1880. It comprised 150 radiates, from Gordian III to Postumus. Only 123 are now recorded.
The central site of Sorte Muld at Bornholm has produced a large number of coins, of which 292 are interpreted as belonging to one original deposition.
The hoard was found in a funerary urn and apparently comprised 50 'small bronzes' or radiates of Gallienus.

This hoard of 64 denarii and antoniniani (Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius) was found in 1846 «Im Lustgarten». The entire hoard arrived in the private collection of Großherzog Leopold, but could not be traced after that.
11 antoniniani (Gallienus - Divus Claudius, AD 270) found on the southwestern slope of the Sommerberg directly above Furtwangen.
The hoard comprised 114 sestertii: Trajan-Gordian III (98-243 AD).
26 bronze coins. Among them, 1 billon coin of Alexandria for Diocletian.
155 bronze coins, official and provincial issues of Viminacium and Provincia Dacia: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised 1,300 coins of which 21 from Philip I to Tacitus (AD 275-276) were acquired by C. Quandalle . These are not considered to be representative of the hoard as a whole, being either rare or issues that Quandalle did not have in his collection. Hobbs estimates a silver weight: c. 235.1-1624.1g.
The hoard comprised nearly 1,500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus to Probus, with coins of Probus being the most numerous. Only one coin of Gallienus' sole reign was described (RIC 599).
c. 1200 silver coins: 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
15 radiates (Gallienus to the Tetrici) from a larger hoard of unknown size discovered while ploughing a field somewhere outside Fishguard. No further details are available.
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: The hoard was found in a sandstone or earthenware vessel hidden in a wall and covered by a large stone. It comprised 19 kg of corroded silver, billon and bronze coins, equating to approximately 3,600 coins. No certainty, that the latest coins belong to Postumus.
Unknown initial number of coins. Y. Youroukova have seen 22 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
2669 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 721.6-3335.3 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLVII

summary: Twenty copper Roman coins from a salt spring: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
9 sestertii found within the south-west district: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 247).
The hoard comprised 283 tetradrachms dated between the reigns of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
(c. 1500) 64 antoniniani (radiates): 8 genuine, 56 copies: Valerian I (Salonina) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c. 390.0 g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 Roman coins including denarii, dupondii, asses and radiates terminating in a single issue of Postumus.
84 sestertii and 1 forgery: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
483 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (unknown number)

summary: 500 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 243 were published: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised 39 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus. They were found under a layer of burnt material and many of the coins were blackened, melted or twisted. 34 coins were minted in Rome, 3 in Viminacium and 1 in Cologne with the latest coin being a Cologne issue from AD 256 to 258. Although TAF notes the mint distribution, they are not assigned to coins of particular emperors.
1,489 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a heap on the floor of the underground room N during excavations of a house.
45 silver coins: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

3000 antoniniani (ranging from Trajan Decius to Tetricus, several of which are imitations) fund in a vessel close to Nieder-Ingelheim. 1174 specimens reached the museum Wiesbaden, the other coins are lost.

The hoard comprised 'a bucketful of Roman coins, fused together with corrosion products. Cochet estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard was more than 300. The coins were antoniniani (radiates) of the third century depicting 10 emperors until Tacitus and Probus.
disposition: Musées d’Angers, France; Accession Register III, p. 37, no. 42 (3.11.1876)

summary: 152 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217). Circumstances of find not known.
A hoard of 300-400 antoniniani (radiates). 336 coins were examined by Salama at the home of a dealer in Tunis on 6.5.1965: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Found by a fisherman amongst rocks off the coast of Ambleteuse. Silver: ? (137) coins; Silver weight: ? (24.8-43.8g)
disposition: Boulogne (statue, cup, spoons); The British Museum (ewer)

summary: A hoard of 299 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Elagabalus) and denarii (Domitian - Severus Alexander) from Dura Europos, found in J 7 W.
22 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic jug in a room of the Roman villa: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
2000 silver coins found during road repairing works: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised approximately 70 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269). Forty-four coins are catalogued.
Hoard of 1,500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found in several amphoras: Clodius Albinus - Gallienus (AD 260-268). Found together with a gold chain.
Four provincial coins (Pella, Cassandrea) found in a grave in Potidaia in 1973.
704 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 683 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 10 asses: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254).
17 bronze coins with the latest issues of Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised 84 coins (probably radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Hostilian, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Valerian II.
4957 radiates to Probus (AD 279), found in a jar, 10 miles south of Oxford. The hoard contained a second specimen of a coin of Domitianus (Domitian II), a Gallic usurper under Aurelian.
356 silver coins: 294 denarii, 62 antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: 490.5-1026.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania (348 coins), County Museum Tg. Jiu, Romania (8 coins)

summary: Hoard of aurei and jewelry: 94 aurei: Nero - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold weight: 648.8g.
928 (589) denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole reign) (AD 267).
disposition: Nikšić Heritage Museum (575 coins), Montenegro; the National Museum of Herceg-Novi (125 coins), Monetnegro; Museum of Titograd = Podgorica City Museum (Muzej grada Podgorice) (225 coins), Montenegro - 1981

summary: 543 denarii (of which 5 plated) found with a pitcher: Nero - Macrinus (AD 218); 1768 g. The mints of Alexandria, Antioch and Emesa are represented by one copy each, while the one from Laodicea by a total of 12 coins.
320 denarii and antoniniani found in a building from the ancient settlement. 22 coins were reviewed: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised 79 sestertii from Vespasian to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A scattered hoard of 23 radiates (Salonina to Victorinus) found within the remains of an enclosed Romano-British farmstead.

A third century hoard of 99 antoniniani (radiates) interpreted as a savings hoard. Found during development control excavation in advance of building new housing estate: Gordian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
933 denarii and 2 antoniniani (radiates) spanning from Mark Antony to Maximinus I (AD 235-238).
10 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 3.7-11.5g.

(100) 75 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 44 denarii, 29 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 101.7-155.2 g; together with irregular pieces of gold (13.5 g) found in a vessel
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (73 coins, gold pieces, and the 3 sherds), Museum of Petroșani, Romania (2 coins)

summary: 698 silver coins: 1 denarius, 697 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: 190.0-1811.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (10 coins of Postumus); collection De Bove (34 coins), in 1882

summary: A corroded metal container was found in 1937, in the garden of a house. It contained either 20-30, or ca. 15 Roman coins. The 4 coins that were inventoried in 1957 are antoniniani dating from Claudius II to Tetricus I. Coins are lost today.
Ca. 100 antoniniani (Gallienus to Tetricus II) found in a pot behind the wall of a Roman house, close to the Schloßplatz. 65 have been described in FMRD, the others are lost.

Over 500 coins were discovered on a parcel by a collector. G. Dembski have seen 68 denarii. Other scholars (Al. Ruske) expressed some doubts about these coins being part of a hoard: Hadrian - Severus alexander (AD 230).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing several thousand (more than 4,000?) coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus 'all in silver, with varying titles'. A list of numbers of types (rather than numbers of coins) exists. The coins were discovered 'by chance' in ancient ruins at the site. Silver: 4000+ (480) coins; Silver weight: 921.7-10397.2+
disposition: Musée d'Orbigny (20 coins), France; Musée de Guéret, France

summary: 30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: Around 700 antoniniani (radiates) found at the foot of the mountain by the mouth of the "Beschterbach" river.
21 denarii: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 233-235).
15 coins: 3 heavily worn out denarii, 12 provincial bronze coins found in a sacred area (sanctuary) in a small dish: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 50 to 60 'copper or bronze coins' found with a ceramic vessel. The better preserved pieces included sestertii of Valerian I and Salonina.
The hoard comprised one ceramic jug and two urns (?) containing 90 kg of coins. 2,777 antoniniani are known: Divus Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Circonscription archéologique de la ville de Souk Ahras

summary: 30 coins: 2 sestertii, 28 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Around 600 silver coins, of which 432 were seen: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised c. 200 antoniniani (radiates) (tpq AD 274).
