The hoard comprised 377 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 198 were studied by Debray: Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Hobbs estimated a silver weight of between 102.8-470.3g.
4-5 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 2 coins are known: Gordian III, Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus Caesar).
3 coins: Marcus Aurelius: denarius, dupondius; Trajan Decius sestertius (AD 249-251).

A hoard of Syrian tetradrachms (668 according to Coin Hoards, 666 according to Bland) ranging in date from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus. It is said to have been found at Iskenderun, 57 km north of Antioch.
57 billon: Hadrian - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 264-265) found as an unprotected heap on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house. Range: Hadrian - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
disposition: 37 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 21 denarii and 28 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
7 coins: Nerva – Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
disposition: Regional museum, Kolín, Czech Republic (6 coins)

summary: Unknown quantity of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzik: Julia Paula, Gordian III, Otacilia severa; silver weight: 8.1-13.5 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 441-445

summary: 54 from the 600 coins are known. All are antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: c.162g.
Circa 80 silver coins. Only 2 of Caracalla, 3 of Gordian III, 1 of Philip I are known.
The hoard comprised 9 antoniniani (radiates). The emperors represented include Gordian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian I, Gallienus and Salonina. There is no catalogue.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: 70+ AR and AE. The coins found in the period 1828-1833 are partly derived from the hoard and partly from discovered complexes. The coins from the complexes may not be included to the coin loss from Voorburg. A total of circa 200 pieces. Coins (81-269): Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gallienus, Postumus.
disposition: Royal Museum of Antiquities, Leiden, Netherlands

summary: 8 coins found in a cave: Antoninus Pius - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II); silver weight: 4.1-13.9g.

This record has been created for the HER record of a hoard of 36 third century Roman coins found in the Waddon New Road, Croydon. The details of this find seem to differ from those associated with Robertson 2000, 235 no. 963: (apparently a fourth century hoard found in 1903) and the tetrarchic hoard of 34 coins found before 1914 associated with Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1047.Seaby's Coins and Medals Bulletin 1961, 234 reports 36 coins found in the Waddon New Road area during the excavation of a cutting between West Croydon and Pitlake in 1814 and in a private collection. Details are unfortunately vague: "All were Antoninianii and the range of dates encompassed only thirty years...Several rulers were represented and all coins with the exception of one originated from the same mint - Rome".

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY, MARLOWE CAR PARK AREA M II
summary: Marlowe Car Park Area M II, scattered hoard of 119 coins, found in flood silts sealing Structure R22. Contains coins of Constantine & Valentinian (intrusive), but also of Carausius, Gallienus & barbarous radiates, latter make up approx.. half of group.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel covered with a copper-alloy plate and comprised approximately 10,000 radiates of Tetricus I, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus and Probus. Only 18 coins were preserved.

Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.
Forty-sevenound with a ceramic vessel. 45 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 211-217).
(c. 250) 216 silver coins: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235), silver weight: 301.0-629.2 g.
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; 204 coins; inv. nos. 843 1-122

summary: 8,400 denarii: Mark Anthony - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further information on Hoard?tructure.

1200-1300 bronze coins, found in a vessel south of the Roman fort, together with a silver ring. The coins were dispersed. 25 of them were described, and 11 further coins are still preserved in the museum Landshut (therefore, 36 are listed in FMRD, ranging from Vespasian to Severus Alexander).

14 bronze coins, ranging from Caracalla to Philip, found in a clay vessel in the destruction layer of a building in the north section of the Agora. More than 100 bronze (provincial, judging from those ill. in fig. 4 in AEMTh 18, 2004, p. 382) coins were also found in the same layer.
Around 100 bronze coins of 'large and medium size' from Trajan to Postumus (?) (AD 260-268).

The hoard consists of 73 coins found with a patera: 5 imperial denarii, 6 antoniniani (radiates), 62 Roman provincial bronzes: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Most of the provincial coins presents early 3rd century AD countermarks.
18 coins : 13 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).

35 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). There is no certainty that this was the total number of the monetary group. The owner could have retrieved part of the coins, as well as the following agricultural works, probably, led to the finding of other pieces.
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania

summary: 12 silver coins: 1 denarius, 11 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Caracalla and Elagabalus.
Two provincial coins, minted in Alexandria (Diocletian and Maximian), found on a field in ca. 1900.

230 antoniniani (radiates) were originally described and were thought to represent approximately 1/3rd of the hoard; however, Hiernard increased the number to 230 and argued that this portion was part of a hoard of approximately 1000 coins. Sagredo San Eustaquio gives the number of coins as 231. The latest coin in the hoard is also the subject of some discussion. Originally a coin of Postumus (AD 260 to 268) with a HERCVLI DEVSONENSI reverse was stated to be the last coin. However, with Hiernard's revisions, 3 radiates of Salonina dating to the period AD 263 to 264 were stated to be the last. Furthermore, Balil basing his observations on Mateu y Llopis, gives the latest coins in the hoard as an issue of Gallienus (RIC 280) and one of Salonina (RIC 5).
Mint distribution is mentioned so can probably be entered at level of coin. Silver: 107, 28 coins; silver weight: 20.3-132.8g.
disposition: Société de recherches de l'Atrèbatie septentrionale

summary: 3503 radiates to Probus, in a pot. Full identifications of all the coins of Probus is unavailable. Unpublished?
Hoard of circa 4,000 coins. 400 coins entered the collection of Gh. Georgescu-Corabia, including issues of Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip I.

The alleged content of a purse comprises 36 mixed denominations (radiates and sestertii) from Trajan to Carinus. The purse was originally located over an abandoned hearth within a taberna in the eastern sector of the so called domus of Titus Macer. Coins originate from different layers; two late Roman bronze coins have to be regarded as instrusions while the connection of a very worn repubblican denarius with the purse is uncertain.
disposition: Aquileia, Archaeological National Museum; University of Padua, department of Cultural Heritage

summary: 25 antoniniani (hoard or purse) bought in 1938 from a drunken labouring man who claimed to have found them in the Dünnern river bed. Coins range from Aurelian to Carinus: 15 Aurelian, 9 Probus, 1 Carinus. 22 coins out of the 25 are clearly identified/preserved today (15 Aurelian and 7 Probus).

Found during excavations, below a destruction deposit in the porticus west of Insula 22. No traces of a container. Purse? Traces of fire. The hoard comprised 12 coins including 11 denarii and 1 radiate terminating AD 243 or 244.
Only 303 antoniniani (radiates) are identified. The exact findspot is not known, but it is possible that it comes from Oudenburg, Gistel or Torhout: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
386 denarii: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 231).
370 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.
(+1000) 92 antoniniani: Gordian - Valerian I (AD 253-259
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (63 coins); dispersed -1981

summary: 1,726 coins found in a bronze vessel: 3 denarii, 1,723 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 293-294); weight: 5,650 kilos.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie de Jura, Lons-le-Saunier, France

summary: A hoard of 14 Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella; Commodus - Gordian III), found in a grave in Peristeronas.
273 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
Unknown number of silver coins. 33 antoniniani seen by T. Gerasimov: Gordian III - Trajan Decius.

Scattered hoard, found in the Dünnern river bed during correction works of the river bed. Over 1100 coins reported, 906 of them preserved. 8 coins from the 1st/2nd c. AD, the others range from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Postumus to Tetricus II. Mostly antoniniani, except for the 1st/2nd c. coins and a denarius of Gordian III. Large numbers of coins from Gallienus and Claudius II.
22 coins were reported on, although it is likely that there were originally a few more (although not many more) in the hoard. Metcalfe suggests that there were originally 26 coins.
517 bronze and electrum Bosporan coins: Rhescuporis II - Ininthimeus (AD 238).
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 51.2-99.8 g.
disposition: Regional History Meseum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1410-1414

summary: The hoard comprised 100 coins 'une centaine'. Gricourt only saw three coins from the find. They were antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip and Herennia Etruscilla. A pharmacist from Somain discovered the hoard which was immediately dispersed.
The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 270 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Aurelian. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 73.9g and 336.5g
Unknown initial number of coins. 264 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9811-10060

summary: 3,598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3,032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard was found in a small wooden box and comprised between 5 and 600 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
Few hundreds coins found with a large ceramic vessel and wonderful jewelry. 53 coins were studied: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 239-241); silver weight: 75.8-153.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Oltenia, Craiova, Romania (53 coins).

summary: (c. 100) 81: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 51.3-104.7 g.
191 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian (AD 274-275) found in a pile at floor level in room during excavations of a house. 1 bronze coin of the Ptolemy V may be regarded as a intruder?
Rescue excavation undertaken by the archaeological service. 20 antoniniani and 3 denarii, ranging from Caracalla to Gallienus (sole reign) were found.
3 aurei: Trajan, Septimius Severus, Caracalla (AD 213).
45 coins found by the farmer Peder Madsen in 1850. The hoard was found collected without a preserved container. The coins were found bundled together beneath a big stone.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus' joint reign and Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269. FMRL suggests that it was a small part of a much larger hoard.

From 57 coins found on the excavated area, according to B. Prokisch 24 coins may have been part of a hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-259). A gold bracelet was found with these coins.

1,051 radiates of the later third century (Valerian to Tetricus I) found at a quarry. According to Lee (1862), the coins were in a "covered pot or pan of common black ware which was unfortunately broken."
16 bronze coins were bought by the museum: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. XXV

summary: The hoard comprised more than 6000 radiates from Julia Domna to Postumus, the most numerous being of Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Found by a workman on the land of B. Flamand
810 silver coins: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 1014.2-2363.7 g.
Hoard of 600 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
500 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: c. 625.6-1298.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1918

summary: Originally a hoard of 68 coins but one went astray. From the 67 remaining coins (62 dupondii and 5 asses), 23 are completely illegible. The coins are heavily worn, suggested a much later burial than the latest coin.
62 coins: 1 aureus, 56 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-256).
158 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Four coins (Syracuse, Augustus, Tiberius for Agrippa and Severus Alexander), allegedly found in the bed of the River Weser at low tide, at 'der Tiefer'. FMRD has listed this find under Bremen-Mahndorf, but doubts that it is genuine.
The hoard comprised 786 or 802 sestertii from Hadrian to Hostilian (or Gallienus, see bibliography).

The hoard comprised a redware ceramic vessel containing more than 200 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which 185 were catalogued by A. Dubiez: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 251.6-568.4g.
disposition: A denarius of Macrinus was acquired for the Claudius Côte Collection in Lyon.

summary: The hoard comprised 23 bronze coins dated between AD 141 and AD 251-253. "The hoard contains a mixture of imperial asses and sestertii, with bronzes from regional 'provincial' mints (Gaza, Ascalon, Caesarea Maritima, Aelia Capitolina, and Nysa-Scythopolis), many of which are countermarked." (Kool, 41).

494 coins found with a bronze vessel: 2 gold medallions, 6 aurei, 486 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 63.6 g.; silver weight: 133.8-1515.2 g. The hoard was found by a farmer. The multiple of Gallienus was acquired by the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.
40 sestertii discovered at 1.40 m depth. Among them 2 of Commodus and 7 or 8 of Postumus (AD 260-268?). No further information.
Unknown initial number of coins. 169 (but there is evidence only on 161 coins) bronze coins were studied: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 266-267).
27 silver coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 250.
1200 denarii found in ceramic vessel. 156 pieces entered the museum collection in Svishtov: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1072-1142

summary: Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 96 coins were described: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
191 silver coins: 132 denarii, 57 antoniniani (radiates), 2 imitations of antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
17 denarii, 11 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 sestertius (separated): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
(200) 162 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: c.251.5-548.5 g. Found together with two bronze bracelets.
1,312 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 249.3g.
HER has a record of "a hoard of 22 antoniniani of the period AD259-273" in Swindon Museum.

The hoard comprised 14 Roman Provincial coins, found in grave 11 in Methone: Dion (1 Elagabalus), Edessa (1 Caracalla, 1 Julia Domna), Thessalonica (1 Geta, 1 Commodus, 2 Elagabalus, 1 Julia Maesa, 1 Philip I), Pella (1 Julia Mamaia, 4 Gordian III).
Six or seven? aurei found in grave no. 3: Gordian III 2, Philip I 3 (AD 244-249) and possibly Hostilian 1 with a drachm of Gotarzes II and 3 denarii of Augustus found during excavations.
22 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found in a little home in a wall during excavations of a house: Carinus (Numerian) - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 294-295).

Coin hoard discovered during the construction of the airfield in Erding, south-east of Langengeisling. Close to the find spot ground walls of a villa rusticate were excavated in 1912. The hoard originally comprised ca. 300 denarii, of which only 96 could be traced (Hadrian - Maximinus I).
(6-700) 23 coins silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
1,602 silver coins: denarii, quinarii, antoniniani (radiates), drachm: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 42 coins including 2 sestertii of Commodus and Balbinus and a silver coin of Attila(sic).
Unknown initial number of coins. 100 denarii: Nero - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Institutul de Cercetări Eco-Muzeale, Tulcea, Romania; inv. nos. 49.717-49.816

summary: More than 100 bronze coins have been found. 68 were seen: Commodus - Gordian III - minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum 35, Marcianopolis 27, Hadrianopolis 3, Anchialus 2, Serdica. 19 are kept in the museum collection in Lyaskovets.
301 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus - Probus (AD 276-282).
(316) 214 silver coins: 23 denarii, 191 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: 112.2-779.3 g.
The hoard comprised somewhere between 2,000 and 2,500 coins, of which a large proportion were taken by the finders. Only 308 coins were catalogued.
A hoard of 7 antoniniani (Gallienus and Claudius II), found in a destruction layer of Monument H in the Sanctuary of Poseidon and Amphitrite.
24 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 22 sestertii and 1 dupondius. The latest coin is a sestertius of Trajan Decius for Herennia Etruscilla (Augusta) (AD 249-251).
Possible part of a larger hoard. Only 4 antoniniani (radiates) are known; silver weight: 5.0g.
261 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
12 antoniniani: 1 Philip, 11 Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 4.2-14 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 969-980

summary: The hoard comprised 1,942 antoniniani (radiates). Three coins (Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus) were given to the perish care taker, four coins (Gallienus) to the collector who helped the finder, of which 1935 were studied by Bastien and Huvelin. Silver: 1869, 66 coins; Silver weight: 505.6-2335.3g.
83 eastern antoniniani (radiates) ranging in date from the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian.

The hoard comprised 2000 coins of 'copper, silver alloy and silver'. In the report compiled by P. Ilarregui the hoard contained pieces of the emperors: Pius Gordianus, Philip, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Gallienus, Saloninus (Caesar), Saloninus (Emperor) and Postumus. A small selection of 10 coins was sent to the Real Academia de la Historia.
disposition: Real Academia de la Historia, Madrid, Spain (10 coins)

summary: 64 antoniniani (radiates) found near a kiln within the south-west district of the Roman city: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 2 asses are known: Nero, Gordian III.
3089 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258).
1,013 silver coins: 1 plated denarius, 1,012 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Aurelian (AD 270-275). The table of hoard structure indicate 1,010 coins.
149 bronze coins of Viminacium and Provincia Dacia. 132 studied: Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255). Mints: Viminacium 120, Provincia Dacia 12.
disposition: National Museum of History, Vranje, Serbia (132 coins).

summary: The hoard (a purse?) comprised 8 coins of Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus and Quintillus.
The find originally comprised 151 antoniniani: Caracalla-Philip I (AD 211-249). Further 36 specimens from the same hoard acquired in 1916.
The hoard comprised 42 bronze coins from Nero to Gallienus including imperial bronzes (sestertii) and Provincial bronzes from Knossos, Kydonia, Koinon of Crete and Alexandreia Troas.
441 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
108 antoniniani (radiates)Ș Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
Unpublished hoard of three denarii in BM file report. Declared Treasure Trove in 1980.
73 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos.1538-1610 (73 coins, 69 have been stolen)

summary: (1200) 290 denarii: Otho - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). Found together with: 1 gold torque of twisted wire, 2 silver torques, 2 silver bracelets, 10 silver appliques, 1 silver brooch, 1 silver ring with inscription.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXXXIX (1934)

summary: The hoard comprised 202 antoniniani (radiates), placed inside a sandstone altar and found in association with a variety of objects in copper-alloy, iron and ceramic. The latest coin is an issue of Postumus dating to AD 266.
The workers discovered a metallic vase with 20 kg of coins (maybe antoniniani). Only 214 are now recorded, from Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland (part of the hoard)

summary: 313 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins: 10 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Commodus - Philip I (244-249 AD).
12 aurei: Galba - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold weight: 73.8-98.7+g.

Unknown initial number of silver coins. According to some information from a private collector the number of coins was between 2,500 and 3,000. 26 coins entered museum collection in Sofia: Otho - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 32865

summary: 286 denarii and 7 bits of gold found with a ceramic vessel using as lid another ceramic vessel: Republic - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235).

In 1958 a small collective find of 18 antoniniani ranging from Aurelian to Carinus Caesar was unearthed in a ditch during excavations conducted by the commission for archaeological exploration of late antique Raetia.
(700) 170 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
41 silver coins: 6 denarii, 35 antoniniani (radiates): septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Caesar) (AD 251).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 247/00)

summary: of 4,033 pieces, 3296 were recorded at the British Museum: 592 denarii, Domitian-Gordian III; 2704 antoniniani, Caracalla-Trajan Decius, including 2 “Divi”. The other were all antoniniani of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II and Trajan Decius.

A large hoard of c. 22,500 gold and silver coins, ranging from Claudius to Maximinus I, found in 1909 during excavation works for the construction of a house on Gertrudenstraße, approx. midway between Wolfstraße and Neumarkt. Of the c. 22,500 coins found, 4513 are identifiable to RIC number. Only part of these coins are preserved today.
While digging for the foundations of a house a ceramic vessel with some tens silver coins was found. 63 pieces were examined: 6 antoniniani, 57 denarii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy spoon and 147 copper-alloy coins from Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Julia Mamaea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip II.
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii from Titus to Gordian III.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 50 coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A hoard of 233 Alexandrian tetradrachms, ranging from Nero to Philip, found 1968 in Abu al-Gud, in the vicinity of Luxor.
34 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 33 silver coins, 1 provincial bronze: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) - Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) (AD 253-260).
The hoard was found mixed in with earth, without an obvious container. The excavators suggested an organic bag.
Around 200 denarii. 7 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235) are known..
101 coins: 96 sestertii, 3 antoniniani (radiates), 2 bronze copies: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260); silver weight: 3.5-6.2 g.
disposition: Local museum, Petigny, Belgium (82 coins); private collection (11 coins), in 1960; Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (8 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 287 denarii: 93 republican, 194 imperial: Republic - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles, Paris, France; collection Favre

summary: 539 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from the sole reign of Gallienus to Aurelianus, incl. Vabalathus. Hoard hidden in the debris of an earthquake dating from AD 241, covering the stadium building.
The hoard comprised 43 sestertii from Commodus to Gordian III (AD 241-243).
(+7000) 5688 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; in.nos. 4054-4238

summary: 51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.
The coins (44 denarii, Vespasian - Severus Alexander) were discovered during excavation in room D of building I of a mansio close to Sigmaringen.
A hoard of 1,545 coins (270 tetradrachms, 1 bronze, 1,274 antoniniani down to Claudius II, AD 270), found during the excavations at Capharnaeum.
12 denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Septimius Severus (AD 201).
38 coins: 9 antoniniani and 29 provincial bronzes found within the ruins of an ancient building: Macrinus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Regional History museum, Dobrich, Bulgaria; inv.no. I 2761

summary: (200) 27 silver coins: 6 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: 251.3-514 g.

During a violent storm in 1991, coins and many other artefacts dating from the Roman Empire, such as pottery vessels and bronze weights, were washed up from the seabed a short distance from the ancient city of Camarina on the most south-easterly point of Sicily. Among issuers: Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Camarina, Italy

summary: About 800 denarii and antoniniani of the 1st-3rd centuries AD.
Originally between 80 and 100 coins were found of which only 2 aurei and 16 denarii were retained: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 214).
disposition: Escuela de Capataces forestales (Castillo de Coca), Madrid

summary: The hoard was hidden amongst a pile of Roman tiles and comprised more than 2,000 sestertii. TAF suggests that the large bronze of Gallienus should in fact be identified as a medallion.
1,156 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) together with 136 bronze coins found in two ceramic vessels ranging from Trajan to Gallienus.
Hoard of initially 90 silver coins. 41 were recovered (denarii, antoniniani (radiates): Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised an enormous pot containing a very large quantity of Gallo-Roman coins. Although some of the coins were stolen soon after their discovery, the number of coins found totaled more than 2,000. Only 85 of these were described. After its discovery, the pot was left in the middle of the field overnight and some coins from the hoard went missing then: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 541.0-2499.1g.
Circa 500 coins, among which: 468 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

49 coins: 2 denarii, 7 antoniniani, 40 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); 28 provincial bronze coins of Marcianopolis and Nicopolis ad Istrum: Septimius Severus - Gordian III; silver weight: 12.1-19.7 g.
2,191 silver coins found with an urn: 2147 denarii, 44 antoniniani (radiates): Mark Antony ´- Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver weight: 3112.7-7821.9g.
disposition: Salzburg Museum Carolino Augusteum (41 coins); Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (10 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 6 aurei and silver jewelry. Two of the aurei are mounted in gold frames. The coins are: Antoninus Pius, Caracalla, Julia Domna, Macrinus and 2 of Severus Alexander (AD 234).
disposition: Musée national des Antiquités et Arts musulmans, Alger, (ex Musée Stéphane Gsell), Algeria; inv.nos. 1045 - 1053

summary: 290 denarii ranging from Marc Antony to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

Unknown initial number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 240 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249). Mints: Marcianopolis, Mesembria, Tomis.
The hoard comprised 12 coins of Gallienus and Tetricus I.

The hoard comprised 113 Roman silver coins of different sizes, bearing the portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Aemilian, Valerian I and Gallienus. Apparently, this list is not exhaustive. The hoard is probably one of antoniniani (radiates), although perhaps some denarii were present.
Unknown originally coin number. 5 antoniniani (radiates) and 87 denarii are known: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
758 imperial and provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 42288-46046

summary: A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.
NA
2611 coins, 2594 recovered: Vespasian - Valerian to Gallienus with some intruders (Divus Claudius II, Constantinopolis). Silver weight: 9,270 kg.
Unknown initial number of coins. 70 pieces are kept in the museum of Lovech: 12 denarii, 29 antoniniani, 29 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Lovech, department of Archaeology, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1675-1676

summary: 1,486 tetradrahms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) in a disintegrated cloth bag on the floor of underground room J during excavations of a house.

In 1981 a hoard of 159 Antoniniani of the last third of the third century (Gallienus - Diocletian, and Gallic Empire) was unearthed during excavations of the Institute for Pre- and Early history of the University of Johannes Gutenberg at Mainz. The hoard was found in a cellar.
2,000 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Dispersend among locals, and buyers from Novara and Torino.

summary: 25 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Hadrianopolis
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1780 1-25

summary: At least 18 radiates (Gallienus to Tetricus I) found in the area of Tintern some time around 1872. It is uncertain that these represent the entirety of what might have been a hoard. No further information is available.

A hoard of ca. 3220 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani), ranging from Antoninus Pius to Postumus, found in a vessel during works at the Erthalstraße in 1886. Some of the hoard was dispersed. 1872 coins are listed in FMRD.
45 denari: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
(c. 200) 112 coins: 110 antoniniani (radiates), 2 bronze copies: Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: c.53.5 g.

The 15 (lost) coins, "mostly poorly preserved middle bronzes from Augustus to Trebonianus Gallus", were found in 1913/14 during earthworks on the edge of a ravine near the Bühren estate. "The coins were scattered over 100 m, 1 m deep."
The hoard comprised a large ceramic vessel containing 62 sestertii of the first to third century AD.
32 silver coins discovered in a small ceramic vessel: 7 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2574

summary: The hoard was found in a hollow stone and comprised 300 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
Unknown originally number of coins. 53 denarii were recovered in two lots: Vespasian – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
535 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. No further information.
Four gold coins found in a female grave: Septimius Severus 2, Philip I and Valerian I (AD 253-260).
4500 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tacitus (AD 276).
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: 500 provincial bronze coins. N. Mouchmov saw 6 of them: Marcianopolis: Septimius Severus 2, Macrinus 1, Elagabalus 1, Severus Alexander 1; Nicopolis ad Istrum: Macrinus 1

A hoard 'buried right before the accession of Diocletian'. It consists of large brozes, especially those of Postumus, middle bronzes and circa 1,200 small bronzes, 5 gold rings and a pendant necklace ".
At 3 m from the findspot of MORCHAIN 1, 7 coins: 1 double sestertius, 2 sestertii, 3 asses, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Titus, Hadrian, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Postumus (AD 264-265).
16 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal-detecting: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257). Unknown initial number of coins.
103 coins: 7 antoniniani, 96 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 17

summary: 20 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 18 sestertii: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised 150 antoniniani (radiates), of which 129 survive from Philip I to Claudius II/Victorinus. This is one of four hoards from the site. Silver weight: 31.3-233.2g.

530 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Mints: until AD 253 Rome (except for 1 Volusian from Antioch); after 253: 72 Rome, 40 Cologne, 1 Milan, 2 Viminacium, 45 unidentified and for Postumus, 334 Cologne and 7 imitations. Silver: 580 coins; Silver weight: 145.0-295.5 g.

104 silver coins from Mark Antony to Caracalla (AD 215): 103 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) found spread in a debris layer in the southwest tower of the city wall. The layer was brought to level the floor after the AD 365 earthquake.

The hoard was found near Keldenich, on the Tanzberg in an earthenware urn that was shattered by the workers who found it. It comprised 10 pound (or 20?) of Roman silver coins. The coins (4000 according to Haupt) were dispersed and only the names of some of the emperors represented were recorded (Vespasian - Severus Alexander).
4 antoniniani: 3 Gallienus (sole), 1 Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard was found in a cemetery and comprised 339 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 293).

Hoard found in a bronze pot during the removal of a fence. It comprised more than 1,100 radiates, mainly from the Gallic Empire (Postumus, at least 763 coins). Bought by J. J. Wilhelm Bachofen-Burckhardt, Basel, but some coins dispersed in trade (ca. 100 coins). In 1925, his heirs sold 472 coins to the Swiss National Museum. Then, in 1941, they sold the container and the remaining coins to the Historisches Museum Basel.
45 bronze coins: 44 sestertii, 1 dupondius: found together in an edifice hypotetically identified as of collegium augustales: Domitian 0- Maximinus I THrax (AD 236-238).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Municipal de Cartagena, Spain

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. 21 were kept in the museum of Elbing: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii: Mark Antony - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and History in Elblag (former Town Museum Elbing) in 1903.

summary: 42 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 12 have been examined: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
79 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
The hoard comprised 54 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus with a FELICITAS AVGVSTI reverse type. The hoard was found 20 meters from the deposit found in 1865 at Fontaine Saint-Aubin.
Around 2,500 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1,800 coins were recovered: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 859.1-1804.1g.
88 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting. Only 44 pieces were available for study.
24 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 67360-67382

summary: Found during construction work, no container reported. Located probably in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Hoard of 2,377 radiates: Gallienus (4), Claudius II (2), Divus Claudius (1), Aurelian and Severina (1115), Tacitus (730), Florian (4), Probus (519), Tacitus or Probus (1).

The hoard comprised 'a ceramic vessel containing more than 300 middle bronzes. They were of Marcia Severa, the young Gordian, Gordian II. They were all different, but all base silver.' It is clear that the coins were radiates, although it is possible that there may have also been some denarii if the identification of coins of Gordian II is correct. The hoard was found by a labourer.

The coins listed here are those reported and declared Treasure at various inquests in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The findspot became public and coins were being regularly found at the site. Their findspot was no longer reported accurately and so the coins should probably be considered together (with caution) as a scattered hoard. It is possible that some of these coins are addenda to hoards 496 and 2634. These two hoards do appear to have been spatially separate, found above and below the Crags respectively, but it has been suggested that a hoard may have been disturbed and spilled over the Crags.
163 antoniniani (radiates) found with a storage jar: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
17 antoniniani (radiates) found while building a house: Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) - Probus (AD 276-282).

80 bronze coins were bought by M. Alexandrov: 1 sestertius, 79 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum 38, Marcianopolis 30, Hadranopolis 4, Anchialus 2, Deultum 2, Augusta Traiana 1, Pautalia 1, Nicomedia 1.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 927-991

summary: 136 large imperial bronzes (sestertii?), well-preserved: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

On 18 March 2018, photos of five Roman provincial bronze coins Prusias ad Hypion: Macrinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244) with countermarks were published on the Ukrainian forum Violity. According to the finder, they were found at the same site on the territory of Khmelnytskyi region. Given the close chronology of the coins and the fact that they were issued by one mint, most likely it was a hoard. Coins: Macrinus (1), Maximunus Trax (2), Maximunus Trax (Maxim) (1), Gordian III (1).

The discovery of gold jewellery, objects and coinage in the Lava Gulf off the coast of Corsica is reputed to have begun in the nineteenth century after a chance find by a coral fisherman. 41 aurei or multiples of aurei first appeared on the antiquities market in 1956 (35 aurei and 6 multiples) followed by further discoveries in 1971 and in 1985. It is reputed to have included between 400 and 600 aurei and multiples of aurei of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian, jewellery and gold finger rings which were melted down, a gold dish with a medallion of Gallienus at its centre, and possibly a gold statuette.
18 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13869/1-18 (17 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 43 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus. It was found in the same area as Oštra Luka II.
51 bronze coins: 18 sestertii, 2 dupondii?, 31 provincial coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). Together, were found bronze finger-rings, and fragments of bracelets.
Three bronze coins: 2 sestertii of Hadrian, 1 double sestertius of Postumus (AD 264-265) found in a layer of ashes in a cellar of a Roman building.
382 coins. 332 coins in the museum in Vidin: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 438-463 (today, less than 300 coins)

summary: A hoard of 64 provincial AE coins of Ionia, Lydia, Caria, Thrace, Macedonia and Cilicia, dating from Antoninus Pius to Salonina. See also Klose, Smyrna, p. 123 (2 specimens, and not 1 as mentioned in Noe).

The hoard comprising a large earthenware vessel covered with a tile containing between 40 and 80kg of silver and billon coinage (denarii and radiates). A catalogue of 4084 coins was given to J. de Witte by the owner. A portion of the assemblage belonging to the finder was sold. ; Silver weight: 737.8-11636.9g.
32 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
19 coins of different bronze denominations scattered on an area of 20 sqcm: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
1 denarius and 350 antoniniani (radiates) found in the neighborhood (ca. 100m) of another hoard (99 antoniniani): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 260 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 2449-251)
Circa 150 silver coins. N. Moushmov studied 28: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
1,937 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Musées Royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: The hoard comprised 8 dupondii, ranging from Titus to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
A small barbarous radiate hoard in the British Museum with the provenance "Beccles, Lowestoft, 1872". No further information.
24 silver coins: 3 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Caracalla - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2372

summary: 4,000 coins found in a ceramic vessel: antoniniani (radiates), double sestertii, sestertii from Postumus, Aurelian, Tacitus and Probus (AD 276-282).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 3 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian I, Philip I 2.
The hoard comprised 34 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus; Silver weight: 33.8g.
Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 50 coins are kept in the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22 092-22 141 (50 coins)

summary: Six coins were found together with the artefacts of this hoard: Domitian bronze coin, Trajan (1 sestertius, 1 dupondius), Hadrian 1 sestertius, Antoninus Pius 1 dupondius, Postumus 1 antoninianus (radiate). The Chaourse Treasure is made up of 39 objects in total, all of which are silver apart from five small vessels and a silvered bronze mirror. There are four large serving platters; one of which has the swastika in its central medallion, another has a gilded figure of the Roman god Mercury holding his caduceus flanked by a ram and a cockerel. In addition, there are plain silver drinking cups, various jugs, two large situlas one of which has an acanthus-scroll frieze, shallow plates, hemispherical bowls (one of which was used for washing hands), flanged and fluted bowls (some with engraved decoration of animals amid floral patterns), some mirrors, an ornate strainer with floral and geometric designs, a statuette of the deity Fortuna and a pepper-pot in the shape of an African slave-boy. (Wikipedia)
(c. 300) 22 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: c. 82.0-374.0 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (7 coins); collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (13 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Estimations are around 150 coins. 102 denarii are documented: Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius Caesar) - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
52 coins: 1 denarius, 31 antoniniani (radiates), 5 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 2 unknown denomination: Vespasian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised 'a large number of coins of various rulers'. It is likely to be the same hoard as one found 'close to Saint Pol' comprising 200 coins mentioned in a letter from the antiquarian Beaucousin to Mionnet
Hoard of circa 60 antoniniani (radiates) with coins from Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
6 aurei: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 255-256). The hoard comprises also gold and silver jewelry and tableware. Gold weight aurei: 32.8-41.1 g; silver weight: 645.2 g
disposition: Museum of the Romano-Gallic civilisation, Lyon; Museé des Beaux-Arts, Lyon

summary: 32 bronze coins: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Around 800 denarii found with a copper alloy vessel: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
195 Roman imperial bronze coins: 192 sestertii, 3 dupondii/asses: Trajan - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
1,333 silver coins from Vespasian to Gordian III (AD 238-244). No description of coins.
disposition: Biblioteca Academiei, Cabinetul Numismatic, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Six aes coins (Augustus - Severus Alexander), found approx. 1 km southeast of Meyendorf in the middle of the 19th c., on the premises of an orchard near Stangenberg. The group also comprised one modern cast sestertius, and a modern belt closure, which casts some doubt on the authenticity of the find.
247 antoniniani (radiates): Gordiasn III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised 14 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 260/1 and 270.
disposition: The University of Michigan Kelsey Museum of Ancient and Mediaeval Archaeology

summary: The coins were found inside a copper-alloy cauldron with a total weight of 45kg. However, the hoard was rapidly dispersed, leaving a total of 2,421 coins, corresponding to approximately 14% of the original find. This is estimated at 10,000 coins.

On discovery, most of the find was melted down and therefore it is difficult to establish the exact content of the deposit. It is reputed to have included 30,000 gold and silver coins. Buried around AD 260. Together were found eight silver statuettes and one silver plate remain from the original treasure.
disposition: Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, The British Museum, London, United Kingdom; Musée des ursulines à Mâcon (copies of the statuettes)

summary: Indeterminable total number of coins found by remains of an important Roman villa. Among issuers: Gallienus, Tetricus I

Over 120 silver coins. Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I (Marcia Otacilia, Philip II), Trajan Decius and Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla). Three coins were bought by the Coin Room of the National History Museum in Bucharest.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (3 coins)

summary: A hoard of 131 provincial coins of Athens (periods VB, VI) and 2 antoniniani of Gallienus, excavated in 1957 from a pit in the floor of a house at the northwest foot of the Areopagus (House B, Agora grid Q 19).
11 silver coins: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 605 (11 coins)

summary: Unknown number of bronze coins. 5 pieces were examined: Caracalla - Elagabalus.

In 1978, Mr. Charles Pire, a coin dealer from Brussels, bought about 500 pieces from a lot of 972 coins found in the region of Amiens. It consisted generally of about fifteen antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Salonina, a dozen of Postumus, a hundred of Victorinus, around 20 of Claudius II, about 300 of Tetricus I and II from the mints of Trier and Cologne. Other 30 pieces consisted of imitations of Tetricus I, large module. 235 coins are presented in detail: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-273); silver weight: 185.7-1213.9 g.
disposition: Private collections: Ms. A. Wattecamps; Mr. S. Genvier; Mr. J.-M. Doyen; Mr. Pire

summary: The total number of coins found is not known although it is suggested to be as 5,000 pieces. Only 251 coins kept in a local collection were studied. Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard was found in a ceramic urn which had been placed in a rectangular cavity under a large flat stone. Within the urn, were 100 small gold Roman coins and 200 in silver and bronze, as well as some bones. The hoard was found by a farmer when he lifted a large flat stone in a field which was bothering him. The farmer sold the coins to a collector with the exception of one coin each in gold, silver and bronze.

Details from HER: 2 coins: 1 of Claudius II Gothicus (AD 268-270), Providentia type; & a local copy (c. AD 270) of Pax Aug type of Tetricus II, with radiate head on obverse.Present location unknown.YAJ 1975, 46: 4.
33 tedrachams from Philip I (Otacilia Severa) - Diocletian. Before the monetary reform of AD 297. Only 16 pieces could be identified.
The hoard comprised 11 sestertii: Hadrian-Philip I (117-246 AD).
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: Circa 50 coins of silver and bronze. Only 36 were bought by the Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste, Italy. Mixed with the rest of the coins in the museum collection

summary: A grave found in the peribolos of the west cemetery of ancient Rhodes (reused in late Roman times) contained a hoard comprising 4 Roman bronze coins: 1 of Aemilianus (in the mouth of the deceased), 1 of the first to second century AD, 1 of Caracalla and 1 of Alexander Severus (beside the head).
109 silver coins: 6 denarii, 103 antoniniani: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 247-248).

The hoard comprises 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Aurelian to Numerian). The first publication by Taracena notes 1 coin of Aurelian and 2 of Numerian. However, Gurt notes 2 examples of Aurelian and 1 of Numerian.
A hoard of 104 Roman coins (Philip I - Probus), found opposite the station of Mehrhoog, on a sand hill. The coins are lost.
The hoard contains in total 18 coins. 1 antoninianus, 17 denarii. Coins of Septimius Severus, Julia Mamea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax, Philip I (AD 244-246).
(40) 20 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: c.14.6-84.0 g.
disposition: Collection Derjicke, Iddergem, Belgium (20 coins), in 1965

summary: 523 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293) found in a jar, hidden in a hole dug out beneath the floor of underground room H, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 507 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard comprised a small greyware vessel containing 50 silver and billon Roman coins ending in issues of Postumus. It was found not far from TAF VIII/2.1 (Oise) (CHRE 3546).

A hoard of 402 denarii and antoniniani (Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus) was unearthed on a property in the Mangelhausen district of Wiesbach. The coins were originally contained together with a golden finger ring in an earthenware jug.
1007 silver coins: 201 denarii, 806 antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together with a silver brooch.
(c. 400) 322 antoniniani/radiates: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (AD 257-258); silver weight: 87.9 - 401.5g+
disposition: National Museum Ljubljana, Slovenia (227 coins); Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (95 coins); dispersed

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 10 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N 0056 /1-10/

summary: 48 coins: 13 antoniniani (radiates), 16 denarii, 17 sestertii, 2 asses: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised an iron vessel containing between 700 and 800 coins of Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
56 denarii found in the Seaside baths complex. Only 31 have survived: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-205).
Approximately 50 sestertii dating to the 2nd and 3rd century, terminating with issues of Trajan Decius
25 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Maximianus I (AD 285-286); silver weight: 4.6-6.8g.
4 coins (Claudius II - Tetricus), found in a garden in Gehrden.

The hoard comprised almost 600 antoniniani (radiates) or imitations. Sauvage examined two lots of 120 and 12 pieces, some of which were acquired by the Musée de Boulogne. A further lot was found in the Musée de Boulogne by Seillier and Leclercq. The rest of the hoard probably comprised barbarous radiates which the museum decided not to acquire: Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) - Tacitus (AD 275-276).

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 3,258 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271). The coins of Postumus (and some imitations) made up a quarter of all the coins studied. The hoard was found during ground levelling works close to the walls of a farm; silver weight: 880.6-5928.0 g.
Hoard of 105 coins of the Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.
A pile of antoniniani were found under a stone. 18 coins were seen: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
+8 kg, c. 2000 (515) antoniniani (radiates): Valerian - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0g (after Hobbs).
5 antoniniani without any certainty that they were part of a hoard: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).

116 coins found in 1870 close to Moneybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed two separate hoards (one consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).
Few kilograms of silver coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement. 15 silver coins were seen: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
1,680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver weight: 2151.6-3837.1 g.
The hoard comprised about 200 silver coins from Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius to Gallienus.
The hoard comprised close to 20,000 coins of which 490 were seen. These included issues of Saloninus, Gallienus and Postumus.
86 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
53 coins (denarii, ranging from Nero to Macrinus) found in a bag, north of the Fort Stahlberg, within the perimeter of the city's hospital.
The hoard comprised c. 1,500 coins from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard contains 37 silver coins (18 denarii and 19 antoniniani-radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259). This hoard has been discovered along with some single coins from the Celts and Romans (sestertii from Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. Y. Youroukova examined 9 pieces: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
A hoard of 402 silver coins: 31 tetradrachms (Marcus Aurelius - Macrinus), 370 denarii (Nero - Caracalla) and one tridrachm (Trajan) found in two jars at Dura Europos.
(100) 12 denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3426-3437; local school in Suhindol (10 antoniniani of Trajan Decius)

summary: Hoard of 207 denarii, 89 identified. From Vespasian to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Bought by a dealer in Belgrade; dispersed

summary: The coins were found in the area of Fleischstraße 68-76 during excavation works for the construction of a store. They lay in a ceramic container (an amphora, according to some sources). Large parts of the hoard came in private possession and its full extent is unknown. FMRD gives three lists, totalling 3595 coins (all antoniniani, ranging from to ): 1) Part 1 (3351 coins; FMRD 3062,2) 2) Part 2 (Private coll.; 25 coins; FMRD 3062,3) 3) Part 3 (218 coins seen by K. Cibis, only a list of emperors is available; FMRD 3062,4) 4) Part 4 (Private coll., 1 coins; FMRD 3062,5)
67 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 95.2-182.9 g.
3,428 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy pitcher: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 922.5-4265.3 g.
disposition: Museo Civico «Ala Ponzone» di Cremona, Italy

summary: 29 bronze coins: 27 setertii, 1 dupondius, 1 dupondius/as: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
77 coins: 11 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates), 12 AR, 10 sestertii 5 AE: Tiberius - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver weight: 31.3-136.1 g.
361 antoniniani/radiate: Gallienus - Tetrachy (AD 292-293)
Unknown initial number of coins found in a copper alloy vessel: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
It comprised 42 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).

The hoard comprised a mass of coins which were concreted together. It is estimated that there were as many as 5,000. However, only 130 examples were cleaned. These were found to be of the emperors Gallienus and Probus.

The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised two vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.
3,510 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius: Philip I - Aurelianus (AD 270-275)

The hoard was found during the excavation of the fill of a Roman well in a previously unknown area of the vicus and comprised 54 radiates from Gallienus (sole reign) to Tetricus II with a tpq of AD 274. The coins were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1990ss-100/10

summary: 310 antoniniani (radiates) found wrapped in a piece of cloth and placed in two ceramic vessels: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274). The Tetricus I coins are imitations.
156 silver coins: 11 denarii, 145 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 55.0-394.8g.
The hoard comprised 5,200, 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramiv vessel: Maximinus I Tharx -Diocletian and Maximian I (before AD 294).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.
92 silver coins: 91 denari, 1 antoninian (radiate): Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 230).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Monetiere di Firenze, Italy (inv.no. 78377-78458)

summary: The hoard contained approximately 450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Vespasian, Antoninus Pius (?),Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Julia Paula, Severus Alexander, Balbinus, Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Postumus. The most abundant were coins of Gordian, Philip I, Gallienus and Postumus. The attribution of coinage to Antoninus Pius is doubtful as the coin described belongs to Caracalla (RIC 277c).
Around thirty antoniniani in freshly minted condition, of Gallienus, Macrianus, and other contemporaneous issuers.

Over 1,054 coins were found, most of them oxidized together. Only 120 have been recorded to the level of the coin. Some 12 coins may have been lost (loose from the bulk of the hoard). Silver: 1054 (1, 127) coins; Silver weight: 285.7-2505.4g.
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins, almost all of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
Few hundreds imitations of antoniniani (radiates), between 500-2,000 pieces of Tetricus I (AD 271-274), 400 studied.
A hoard of 42 denarii, 294 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 provincial coins, found during excavation at the 'podium temple' in Alexandria Troas. Coins range from Septimius Severus to AD 260.
(160) 130 silver coins: 129 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 239); silver weight: 181.8-353.2 g.

A hoard of at least 121 denarii and antoniniani (Septimius Severus - Valerian I), found by two metal detectors in 2006. Some coins were preserved in fragmentary form and these fragments could account for another 1-3 specimens.
Circa 500 antoniniani. Only 11 pieces were described in the first publication.
800 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further Information.
259 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerianus I (AD 257)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania Bucharest 1971 (194 coins); ing. Octavian Lucian (65 coins) in 1971

summary: The hoard comprised 12 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Salonina, Saloninus and Postumus.
158 coins: 7 denarii, 151 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21275-21281 (7 denarii); inv.nos. 5224-5376 (151 coins)

summary: A hoard of approximatively 400 silver coins discovered within a ceramic vessel, comprising a large majority of denarii (Trajan - Severus Alexander) and some Cappadocian drachms (up to Caracalla). The hoard was dispersed. Different accounts exist of its content, with Dundua 1979 publishing the 377 coins in the National Museum in Tbilisi (12 Cappadocian drachms and 365 denarii) and Zograf 1945 listing 417 coins (10 Cappadocian drachms and 407 denarii).
A hoard of 25 aurei (Faustina I - Trajan Decius), one medallion of Gallienus and 16 articles of jewellery, found at Octavian Augustus Street in the ancient Jewish quarter in Alexandria.

The hoard derives from the collection of the musician Simon Antoni, which was acquired by the Kreuznach museum in 1888, with an inventory of 1488 Roman coins. Of these, some coins were found 'am Lemberg', probably between 1830 and 1860. FMRD lists 102 antoniniani, ranging from Valerian (for Saloninus) to Tetricus.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 2,000 small bronze coins of the Late Empire, including issues of Galerien [sic for Valerian], Gallienus, Claudius II and a considerable quantity of Tetricus I. A large number of coins were illegible. Blanchet mistakenly doubled the total of the coins in the hoard and placed it in the parish of Aubigné-Racan.
18 bronze coins found in a grave: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249)
331 coins : 322 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 8 uncertain sestertii: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 232).
The hoard comprised 215 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 268.
disposition: Brodsko Posavlje Museum, Slavonski Brod, Croatia

summary: A possible hoard (or part of a hoard) of 40 sestertii from Trajan to Valerian I (AD 253-254)?

Unknown number of coins found in the vineyard, on an ancient settlement area. 30 coins of Gordian III are known: 15 antoniniani for Gordian III, 15 provincial bronzes minted in Deultum for Tranquilina.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 2,000 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263. Only 701 coins were catalogued. Note that for Gallienus, Valerian II, Saloninus, Salonina and Postumus, mints are given according to RIC (Lyon), not Elmer (Cologne).
The hoard comprised 21 sestertii and 2 dupondii or asses from Trajan to Severus Alexander. It was found on an ancient floor surface in the corner of a room during archaeological excavations.
1,937 antoniniani (radiates) found in a cooking pot: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 263).
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.

A hoard of 50-60 antoniniani, ranging from Gallienus to Maximian I, uncovered in 1961 at the construction of a garage. Further particulars about the find circumstances are unknown. Only 40 coins have been described.

111 denarii, 29 antoniniani (radiates) and one sestertius, ranging from Hadrian to Trebonianus Gallus (Hostilian). The coins that make up this hoard were found a ceramic beaker, which was found in a pit in the northwest corner of a house that contained a metal workshop for bronze. Fragments of a 1:1 bronze statue (possibly an imperial statue) were found close to where the beaker with the coins was discovered.
26 silver coins: 17 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 251); silver weight: 35.5-53.2 g.
Five Antoniniani found together on the 'Tokenberg', in Göstrup-Hüttenhau. These may be part of a larger find.
575 denarii: Nero – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Ritual deposit. Found during a metal detectorists' illegal survey. 2 antoniniani, Gordian III and Philip the Arab.
1170 silver coins: M. Aurelius - Philip I; Silver weight: 1463.8-3029.0 g.
2,634 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Carus (AD 283).

A hoard of 265 provincial bronze coins (of which 202 were identifiable), found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 15, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).). Many of the coins were badly preserved. 63 illegible coins were are not listed in Bellinger's Final report.
(+630: 30 aurei, +600 denarii and antoniniani) 557 coins: 18 aurei, 31 denarii, 508 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 15

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. 84 coins recovered: Antoninus Pius -Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 25.0-216.1 g.
77 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I

Hoard 8 was found on 18 Nov. 1932 and hoard 9 on 22 Jan. 1933. Both were under the floor of the same room, just west of the South-West Tower of the Citadel and certainly part of the same deposit. it comprised 2,821 coins and 11 illegible ones, including one AE of Seleucus III, one tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus, 2 denarii (Severus Alexander) and 2,817 provincial bronze coins from a large variety of mints (Domitian - Decius).

Several reports mention several silver coins (probably a hoard) ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found on the Flürener Heide, on a sand hill, close to Diersfordt, Flüren. The coins have been dispersed.
5 denarii found with a bronze item in a well: Trajan/Hadrian - Caracalla/Elagabalus. (201-222).

According to Liger, the hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 62 coins of the Early Empire. However, according to Barbe, there were 15 coins discovered in the vessel including one of Claudius II. TAF notes that Liger often exaggerated his descriptions of hoards.
17 provincial bronze coins of Caracalla found in a ceramic vessel: Serdica 13, Deultum 2, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1.
(c. 7-8000) 5103 silver coins: 3 denarii, 5100 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Tetrarchy (AD 294)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium; Archaeological Museum, Arlon, Belgium

summary: 276 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver weight: 387.6-713.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (3 coins); May 1967, 273 coins and the vessel

summary: Uncertain total number of coins. 138 coins: 6 antoniniani, 7 silver coins, 3 sestertii, 122 provincial bronzes: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver weight: 5.8-31.6 g.

Hoard found during railway construction work, in a copper-alloy vessel (not preserved). Mainly Tetricus or Tetricus imitations (N. Dürr, Beobachtungen zur römischen Münzprägung. JbHMB 1953, p. 34, mentions Bonosus - this is wrong!). More than 5,000 coins. 5% of these were coins of Claudius II (mainly Consecration issues, mostly of barbaric fabric).
200 coins were discovered. Among them coins of Philip I.
13 antoniniani: Gallienus - Tacitus (AD 276).
A hoard of 376 denarii (Mark Antony to Severus Alexander), found in an earthenware pot while digging a trench on the O'Sullivan Building Estate, in Forest Way, Orpington in July 1934.

About 800 denarii (Mark Antony to Caracalla) and fragments of a possible ceramic container found by workmen digging a ditch near Bron-y-Berllan farm. The original size of the find is uncertain; Davies (1929) records that the workmen who made the find pocketed an unknown number of coins, and that the remainder of the hoard was split between the British Museum (18 coins) and the Verney family of Bodelwyddan Castle, Anglesey. The size and condition of the hoard cannot be accounted for until 1918, when only 333 coins were transferred from Bodelwyddan to the Bangor museum. Robertson's examinations of the hoard in 1937 and 1948 identified 350 coins split between Bangor and the British Museum; the whereabouts of the remainder are unknown.
disposition: Storiel Museum, Bangor (c. 300 coins); British Museum (18 coins)

summary: 10 coins (denarius, as, dupondius) from Republic to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
10 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Claudius II to Probus (276-282) found in a grave.
The hoard comprised 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian II with a tpq of AD 258. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 65g.
Hoard of 99 electrum and silver stateri of the Bosporan Kings, Cotys III and Sauromates III (AD 232-233).
The hoard, found with a bronze vessel, comprised approximately 1,200 radiates from Claudius II to Diocletian (AD 287-288); silver weight: 133.5-237.1 g.
15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised a white ceramic vessel containing 84 or 85 worn sestertii of Augustus to Trajan Decius. In 1901, a further 5 dupondii and asses of Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian and Faustina I were found, as well as a worn sestertius and a potin Iron Age coin depicting a horse surmounted by lyre. It is likely that these coins formed part of the earlier hoard.
61 silver coins found in a Roman villa: 22 denarii, 39 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 100.8-168.5 g.

Two radiate minimi (8 and 7 mm, 0.40 and 0.34 g., one with head to left, and one from dies too big for the flan), found with 'about seven others' and a coin of Victorinus (Elmer 743, slightly worn) were discovered on the 13th tee of Pyle and Kenfig golf-course, before 1955. There were also some fragments of pottery.
disposition: National Museum of Wales (part); Grosvernor Museum (part)

summary: Grave goods: aurei of Elagabalus, 2 denarii Augustus, 2 drachms Gotarzes.

A hoard of 159 provincial bronze coins (Septimius Severus to Philip I) and 73 illegible coins, found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 14, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).

10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 4, Philip I 5, Trebonianus Gallus (Volusianus Augustus) 1 (AD 251-253). Weight coins: 35.74 g. Found together with two silver bracelets and two Anchor type silver brooches and one bronze ring. Weight jewelry: 186.83 g.
67 antoniniani (radiates): 57 Gallienus (sole), 10 Salonina (AD 260-268).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M 999.08.1-M 999.08.67)

summary: The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel and comprised 114 antoniniani (radiates). TAF comments that the presence of the coin of Magnia Urbica is very unusual. It questions whether this coin was added to the hoard after its discovery or whether the hoard was only part of a larger assemblage. The hoard was found in a hole surround by a large amount of masonry (possibly ancient) during the demolition of a fifteenth century building: . Silver: 113 coins; Silver weight: 31.5-140.3g.
Hoard 141 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). Weight: 484.16g.
Hoard of 14 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings, Sauromates II (4) and Rhescuporis III (10) (AD 225).
In 1835, a hoard of 12,000 coins was found there. Hundreds of antoniniani (radiates) of the Gallic emperors were discovered in 1852.
Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: (?) 17 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Julia Domna, Gordian III, Valerian I, Gallienus, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised a large number of denarii and radiates, although only 160 were recorded and were issues from Septimius Severus to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 50.3g to 413.7g.
4,000 antoniniani (radiates). 1967 were available to identify the issuers: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

Hoard of circa 1,200 'large bronzes' found with a large ceramic vessel: Trajan - Aemilian (AD 253). The largest number of coins belonged to Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Rare issues of the emperors Pertinax, Clodius Albinus, Gordian I and II,

The hoard comprised two aurei of Commodus, some silver denarii and an unknown number of bronze denominations. A further three solidi, including one of Constantine I and one of Constans, as well as a poorly described issue were also found although it is to be doubted whether they formed part of the hoard.
Over 248 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gordian III - Gallienus (sole)(AD 260-268).
disposition: Museum of Vojvodina, Novi Sad, Serbia (230 coins), Vl. Macković collection Novi Sad, Serbia (18 coins) - 1982

summary: The hoard comprised 110 coins from Hadrian to Gordian (III?) along with Roman pottery.

The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing a hoard of coins and jewellery. The jewellery included a gold necklace, 3 gold intaglio finger rings, a gold and silver intaglio finger ring and an iron finger ring with silver decoration. The number of coins in the hoard is not known with any certainty. Pérot claims there were 100 sestertii and 150 denarii, whereas Clément catalogued 92 coins, including 67 bronzes (mostly sestertii) and 25 denarii (and radiates?). There were some identification errors with 1 sestertius and 2 denarii attributed to Antoninus Pius, when in fact they were issues of Caracalla.
The hoard comprised 19 Provincial bronzes of Severus Alexander issued in Caesarea Maritima.
27,735 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 294); + 3 silver plates; c. 114 kg
51 coins: 50 sestertii and 1 as with 2 fibulae found in a looted Roman building
It comprised c. 400 silver coins. Only 149 are now recorded: 148 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimus Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole).
17 coins: 16 denarii, 1 dupondius: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241); silver weight: 23.9-44.2 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruzelles, Belgium (1 coin); Collection H. Verlooy of Vilvoorde (16 coins), in 1967

summary: Funerary find. 'A large number of coins finds' between large Stone blocks. Near the place were found human bones and funerary inventory. The 30 coins analyzed revealed antoniani of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus and Claudius II (AD 268-270). No further Information.
disposition: Society of Natural History Savoie (30 coins)

summary: 87 silver coins found in the "Ancient theater": Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,968 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). 1,862 of these coins were identifiable (219 denarii and 1,643 antoniniani (radiates) and form the basis of a catalogue by Le Gentilhomme (1946). The current hoard catalogue outlined here needs checking against this original publication.
The hoard comprises 232 cast denarii: a rejected series of coins depicting emperors from Vespasian to Elagabalus with a tpq of AD 218-222 or soon after.
disposition: National Union Musem, Alba Iulia, Romania (Inv.no. 7438-7673)

summary: Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 103 coins entered museum collection in Stara Zagora: 5 denarii, 96 antoniniani, 2 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 4318-4327

summary: 29 antoniniani (radiates) found buried under the floor and covered with a tegula: Gallienus (sole) - Divus Claudius II (AD 270).
17 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. Only three coins are known: Claudius II 1, Aurelian 2 (AD 270-275).
2,290 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: Commodus - Valerian I (AD 257-259).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 4,000 plated coins. The hoard was found by workmen digging ditches on the ancient route from Mans to Paris.
Around 25 kg = 7,656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 16 sestertii from Hadrian to Philip I and 25 denarii and radiates from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 253-260).

Around 500 radiates (Valerian I to Diocletian) found by a workman in a rock crevice inside a coal mine near Aberkenfig. The coins were apparently lying on a fragment of decayed cloth, suggesting a container. Three different lists of this hoard exist, totalling c. 530, 500 and 492 coins. The list here follows the one given by Robertson, based on the 492 coins deposited at the National Museum Cardiff.

110 denarii and 1 radiate to Elagabalus, discovered 1999 in a Buckinghamshire field, with an addenda of 2 denarii (Trajan and Caracalla Caesar). On the same day in the same field a hoard of nummi was also found, the 'Prestwood B' hoard.
820 coins of which 818 are preserved, all imitation of antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Claudius II (Divus), Tetricus II.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Badajoz, Spain

summary: A small hoard of 13 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Maximin I Thrax (AD 235-238) was discovered in October 2018 in Crimea, probably in its eastern part. Information about the find and a general photo of the coins were published on 21 October 2018 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder himself identified the coins as “purse of denarii”. The coins have a very good preservation. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
14 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 19

summary: The hoard comprised 57 radiates recovered by excavators from the Touring Club de France in 1966. To these it is possible to add another 40 coins of the same date found at the same findspot in 1899 and likely to be part of the hoard. The hoard was found on two separate occasions. The first coins were found in 1899. The circumstances of their discovery are unknown. A second group of coins were then discovered during an archaeological excavation in 1966. Silver: 9, 48 coins; Silver weight: 2.7
11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-246).
