7 denarii: Trajan 1, Marcus Aurelius 1, Severus Alexander 1, uncertain 4.
17 sestertii and middle bronzes from Augustus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
It comprised 3,000 antoniniani from Gallienus, Claudius II, Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Found with a copper vessel.
265 coins: 264 antoniniani, 1 bronze: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
7 antoniniani: Tacitus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
25 coins: 1 denarius, 12 antoniniani (radiates), 2 quadrantes, 10 unknown denomination: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised an 'unknown number of sestertii and 12 silver coins of Gordian III': Nerva - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
359 billon coins. Acquired by J.P. Six together with another two (?) hoards, consisting in Ptolemaic bronze coins and 178 Roman folles respectively.
3456 antoniniani: Valerian I - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 623.2-4318.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 326 - N 328

summary: 22 silver coins found in an ash layer at a Roman sacrificial place.
It comprised c. 150 sestertii. 145 had been studied from Trajan to Gordian III.
It comprised 600 antoniniani (radiates) coins of Claudius II. No further details.
(750) 639 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 937.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 468-1108 (641 coins)

summary: Two aurei found in a lead sarcophagus: Trajan Decius, Tacitus (AD 275-276).
(4033) 3296 silver coins recorded: 592 denarii, 2704 antoniniani: Domitian to - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: The British Museum, London, United Kingdom

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 9 aurei, some gold jewellery and a jet amulet. Gold: 9 coins; Gold weight: 45.4-46.0g. The entire hoard was acquired by Dr. E. Poncet for his private collection.

A hoard of 16 denarii (Vespasian - Caracalla), found in 1832, approx. 20 min from the so-called stone bridge between Rhede and Borken, on a field in Vardingholt. The coins were sold in 1843 at auction in Münster.
Aurei found in a Germanic princess grave. Three of the coins, pierced, where part of a necklace: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius(2). One in the mouth: Gallienus. Rich funerary inventory.
disposition: Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens, Weimar, Germany (inv. nos. 16-19)

summary: 475 silver coins: 1 Celtic drahm, 1 provincial drachm, 3 republican denarii, 470 imperial, found in the river near the former Postumius Bridge pillar. It was presumed that the coins may have been kept in a chest/box: Celtic - Gordian III (AD 240).
disposition: Musei Civici di Castelvecchio di Verona, Italy

summary: The hoard was found in a copper-alloy bucket or situla and comprised 76 sestertii, 4 dupondii or asses and 1 radiate from the Flavian period to Gordian III and 65 bronzes of Postumus. These included 7 doubles sestertii from the mint of Cologne, 17 'large bronzes' from an uncertain mint, 23 'middle bronzes' of which many were cast and 18 bronzes of a size and weight which would suggest that they were imitations.

(+485) 472 silver coins: 106 denarii, 366 Septimius Severus - Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257/258. The coins were minted at Antioch (5 coins), Milan, Rome and Viminacium but data concerning the number of coins from each mint was not recorded. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 598g to 1241.7g. The coins were accompanied by eight pieces of jewellery: a tubulus, part of a chain; a conical tubulus, part of a chain; the fragment of a bracelet; a fragment of a bracelet; three parts of the coil of a bracelet; a piece of semi-circular sheet-metal, part of a chain.

The hoard comprised between 800 and 1000 antoniniani/radiates including coins of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II and Quintillus (AD 270). The exact size of the hoard is not known as the hoard was not preserved as a whole. Found together with a ceramic vessel.
A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.
